# West Coast Powerhouse Joins The Biglaw Compensation Party
## This firm is starting the New Year off on the right foot. Congrats!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 5, 2024 at 10:02 AMJanuary 5, 2024 at 9:50 AM
15
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/wilson-sonsini-compensation-2024/&text=West%20Coast%20Powerhouse%20Joins%20The%20Biglaw%20Compensation%20Party)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/wilson-sonsini-compensation-2024/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/wilson-sonsini-compensation-2024/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Happy New Year! What better way to celebrate than by ushering in a new compensation scale for associates?

Yesterday afternoon, Wilson Sonsini — a firm that brought in $1,354,000,000 gross revenue in 2022, putting it at No. 33 in the most recent Am Law 100 — delighted associates (and of counsel, too!) by announcing raises and bonuses in line with the Cravath scale. This is what the new compensation grid looks like at the firm, effective February 1, 2024:



The firm is also following the Cravath scale for year-end bonuses. Take a look:



Associates must have billed at least 1950 hours to be bonus eligible — and it’s certainly worth noting that the first 40 hours of an associate’s time off at the firm will be considered billable. Bonuses will be paid on Wednesday, January 31.

Congratulations to everyone at Wilson Sonsini!

(Flip to the next page to read the full memo from the firm.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of compensation updates, so when your firm announces or matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or email us (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus/Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for your help!

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. # How To Help Recruiters Alert You To Relevant Opportunities On LinkedIn
## If your LinkedIn profile doesn’t clearly communicate your skills and specific experience, recruiters are left to guess.
By [CHRISTINE BERGER - LATERAL LINK](https://laterallink.com/team/christine-berger/)  
onSeptember 16, 2022 at 12:12 PMSeptember 16, 2022 at 11:51 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/how-to-help-recruiters-alert-you-to-relevant-opportunities-on-linkedin/&text=How%20To%20Help%20Recruiters%20Alert%20You%20To%20Relevant%20Opportunities%20On%20LinkedIn)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/how-to-help-recruiters-alert-you-to-relevant-opportunities-on-linkedin/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/how-to-help-recruiters-alert-you-to-relevant-opportunities-on-linkedin/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It won’t come as a surprise to you that virtually every recruiter uses LinkedIn to source candidates. You’ve likely received at least a few unsolicited LinkedIn messages from recruiters. Chances are, some of those messages were for positions that do not align with your practice area. This can be a source of frustration, leading some lawyers to become pretty jaded about the general notion of recruiter outreach.

But here’s the thing. If your LinkedIn profile doesn’t clearly communicate your skills and specific experience, recruiters are left to guess. The best way you can improve the quality of recruiter outreach is to maintain an informative, up-to-date profile. This gives recruiters quick and valuable insight into your background, enabling us to contact you if there’s a strong match and, conversely, to move on if you’re obviously not the right candidate. I can’t promise that a more informative profile will entirely solve the problem of messages for irrelevant roles, but it will definitely help.  

Introduce yourself effectively

The “intro” portion of your LinkedIn profile (the top section) is in many ways the most important. This is your opportunity to communicate crisply who you are and what you offer. The best way to enable a recruiter to find your profile is by inserting informative keywords into the “headline” (the line immediately below your name). Describing yourself simply as an “Attorney” is a missed opportunity: instead, tell us what type of attorney you are. The more specific, the better. For example, “Litigation Attorney” is better than “Attorney.” But the best is a headline like “Litigation Employment Attorney Specializing in Discrimination and Retaliation.”

Double-check that your location is current. Many lawyers moved cities during the pandemic, and some have neglected to update their LinkedIn profiles accordingly. It only takes a moment! While you’re at it, consider selecting the “open to opportunities” setting that is only visible to recruiters. This will confidentially communicate to recruiters that you’re receptive to relevant outreach.

Photos are another critical element of an effective intro section. Adding a photo increases the likelihood that a potential contact will accept your connection request by 9x. In addition to uploading a professional profile photo, make sure to include a background photo. Your background is a visual representation of your personal brand and is one of the first things recruiters will see when they visit your profile.

Fill in the details

A basic rule: if it’s there, fill it in. The more complete your profile, the better. Obviously, you have to fill out Experience and Education. But beyond that, add some content to Skills (in case recruiters are filtering on those keywords) and your licenses and certifications (you’re a member of a bar, right?). Other optional sections can help give your profile a more personal touch. Are you bilingual? Fill out the Languages section!

Ensure that your Experience section is more informative than a simple list of titles. The nice thing about LinkedIn, in contrast to a resume, is you don’t have to worry about fitting all the content onto a printed page. So go ahead and include a couple of bullet points about each of your past positions to indicate specifically what you did and what you achieved. Naturally, this will change over time as you advance in your career and accomplish new things, so don’t just fill in the Experience section once and forget about it — be proactive about keeping the description of your current role up to date. As a matter of style, note that it’s perfectly appropriate to write in the first person on LinkedIn, in a way that would be uncommon on a resume. Using “I” statements helps to humanize you.

Education should be fairly straightforward, but do keep in mind that this is not the place to be modest. If you graduated with honors, say so. You may also wish to list your GPA and/or class rank, especially if you’re early in your career, with limited work experience.

Stay active

At a minimum, you should log into LinkedIn weekly to check your messages. If you aren’t in the habit of logging in regularly, you can also put your contact info (personal email and/or cell phone) on your profile, enabling recruiters to contact you through those alternative channels.

As an optional bonus, consider creating content on LinkedIn. This will boost your ranking in search results and can be a great way to get noticed — not just by recruiters, but maybe even by law firm partners directly. Being active on the platform builds credibility, demonstrating that you know your area of law and are comfortable speaking about it publicly. This is by no means required, but when you do it well, it certainly helps!

Check your search appearances 

Be sure that you are getting noticed by the right audience. To do this, go to your profile page, look under the Analytics heading, look for the magnifying glass icon, and click on “search appearances.” This lets you see how often you appear in search results. In addition to the number of search appearances, it also shows you the keywords you were found for. If these do not align with your current practice area or industry, consider adjusting your headline and intro section until you are appearing in more targeted searches. 

Have fun 

Finally, have fun. Networking and being open to new opportunities can be intimidating, but LinkedIn makes it relatively simple and stress-free. Treat it as a no-pressure environment for you to be yourself and engage with like-minded people.

####Topics

# Biglaw Firms Finally Speak Up In Wake Of SCOTUS Leak, And They're Prepared To Defend Abortion Rights In America
## Lawyers, it's time to assemble!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 2, 2022 at 12:42 PMJune 2, 2022 at 11:27 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/biglaw-firms-finally-speak-up-in-wake-of-scotus-leak-and-theyre-prepared-to-defend-abortion-rights-in-america/&text=Biglaw%20Firms%20Finally%20Speak%20Up%20In%20Wake%20Of%20SCOTUS%20Leak,%20And%20They’re%20Prepared%20To%20Defend%20Abortion%20Rights%20In%20America)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/biglaw-firms-finally-speak-up-in-wake-of-scotus-leak-and-theyre-prepared-to-defend-abortion-rights-in-america/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/biglaw-firms-finally-speak-up-in-wake-of-scotus-leak-and-theyre-prepared-to-defend-abortion-rights-in-america/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As the Supreme Court enters its homestretch, time continues to tick down on abortion rights in America. Thanks to a leaked draft opinion by Justice Samuel Alito in the Dobbs case, we now know that the Supreme Court is ready, willing, and able to overturn nearly 50 years of precedent to take away the right to choose. With the final opinion set to be released any day now, Biglaw firms have entered the scene, prepared to protect the rights of those who will be affected should Roe v. Wade be struck down by the high court.

An alliance of 23 major law firms has been formed — the Legal Alliance for Reproductive Rights — and their goal is to provide free legal services to those in need should Roe fall.

Teresa Johnson, co-chair of Arnold & Porter Kaye Scholer’s capital markets practice and one of the founders of the group, noted that because SCOTUS is on the precipice of “tak[ing] away a fundamental right that has been on the books for nearly 50 years,” it “calls for a public-private collaboration to pool our strength and resources.” The [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/06/01/big-law-steps-up-to-defend-abortion-rights-if-roe-falls/) has the details on how the alliance plans to help:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Under the terms of the alliance, firms will provide pro bono representation when pregnant people and providers face civil suits and criminal charges related to seeking or providing abortions in California and other states. Member firms will also assist in pro bono civil and criminal defense in other states where the right to choose no longer exists, according to a statement on the formation of the alliance.

Johnson said, while the alliance was still taking shape, matters with which it could assist include defense in vigilante lawsuits against pregnant people, providers and assisters; representation of providers who receive subpoenas seeking records; advising hospitals, clinics and medical professionals on policies relating to the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, partnering with public defenders to assist in the criminal defense of people who have had abortions in states where the action is criminalized; and even affirmative litigation, including constitutional claims relating to blocking harmful state laws—like travel bans.

According to Johnson, the alliance — which will be led by San Francisco city attorney David Chiu — is a “dream team” of law firms “ready to meet the challenge” that lies ahead. Those law firms include:

- Altshuler Berzon
- Arguedas Cassman Headley & Goldman
- Arnold & Porter Kaye Scholer
- BraunHagey & Borden
- Clarence Dyer & Cohen
- Conrad Metlitzky Kane
- Crowell & Moring
- Durie Tangri
- Farella Braun + Martel
- Glenn Agre Bergman & Fuentes
- Hanson Bridgett
- Keker Van Nest & Peters
- Lewis & Llewellyn
- Lieff Cabraser Heimann & Bernstein
- Moeel Lah Fakhoury
- Morrison & Foerster
- Nassiri & Jung
- Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe
- Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison
- Ramsey & Ehrlich
- Rogers Joseph O’Donnell PC
- Swanson & McNamara
- Willkie Farr & Gallagher
“During this moment when fundamental rights are at stake,” Chiu said, “we welcome legal communities around California and our country to join us.” Is your firm ready to join the members of the Biglaw and boutique abortion avengers to form an even stronger team? Your help is sorely needed, and it’s time to assemble. Please join the squad today.

# Cyberattack Forces Biglaw Firm To Take Document Management System Down For Weeks
## The firm seems to have recovered after the incident.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 6, 2023 at 5:47 PMJanuary 6, 2023 at 3:25 PM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/cyberattack-forces-biglaw-firm-to-take-document-management-system-down-for-weeks/&text=Cyberattack%20Forces%20Biglaw%20Firm%20To%20Take%20Document%20Management%20System%20Down%20For%20Weeks)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/cyberattack-forces-biglaw-firm-to-take-document-management-system-down-for-weeks/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/cyberattack-forces-biglaw-firm-to-take-document-management-system-down-for-weeks/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We are confident that our process has been professional and appropriate. In fact, I am proud to say that we have received overwhelming praise from our clients for our transparency and the professionalism of our response to this attack.

— [Pat Quinn](https://www.cadwalader.com/professionals/pat-quinn), managing partner of Cadwalader, in a statement given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/01/05/november-cyberattack-hobbled-cadwalader-for-weeks-internal-emails-show/), concerning the firm’s response to a mid-November cyberattack that forced the Am Law 100 mainstay to wipe hard drives and take many of its systems offline, some of them for weeks (like its internal document management system). Quinn went on to note that the firm quickly informed clients about the issue and hired “renowned external cybersecurity experts and legal counsel.” Cybersecurity experts told Am Law that Cadwalader’s response was in-line with industry best practices.

# Stat Of The Week: Law Firm Mergers Bounce Back
## Will 2021 see a return to triple digits? 
By [Jeremy Barker](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jbarker/)  
onApril 9, 2021 at 6:01 PMApril 9, 2021 at 2:44 PM
15
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/stat-of-the-week-law-firm-mergers-bounce-back/&text=Stat%20Of%20The%20Week:%20Law%20Firm%20Mergers%20Bounce%20Back)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/stat-of-the-week-law-firm-mergers-bounce-back/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/stat-of-the-week-law-firm-mergers-bounce-back/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Law firm mergers set a record in 2019, before the pace fell dramatically as the pandemic took hold. Now, mergers are again poised to hit the triple digits, according to a new report.

[As noted by Reuters](https://today.westlaw.com/Document/I73d73450970b11ebb2cbbf0d2509a923/View/FullText.html?transitionType=SearchItem&contextData=(sc.Default)), an Altman Weil survey tracked 26 mergers in the first quarter of this year — short of the pace of 2019, which saw 115, but up substantially from last year’s 65. These include Winston & Strawn’s acquisition of Scheper Kim & Harris and Crowell & Moring’s pick-up of Kibbe & Orbe.

As Altman Weil’s Thomas Clay told the publication, “We wouldn’t be surprised to see law firm merger and acquisition totals back over 100 by year-end.” 

[Will law firm mergers break 100 this year? Q1 report says they’re on their way](https://today.westlaw.com/Document/I73d73450970b11ebb2cbbf0d2509a923/View/FullText.html?transitionType=SearchItem&contextData=(sc.Default)) [Reuters] 

Jeremy Barker is the director of content marketing for Breaking Media. Feel free to [email him](mailto:jbarker@breakingmedia.com) with questions or comments and to [connect on LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jeremy-barker-5316a230/).

# New Raises Are Like Catnip For Associates At This Biglaw Firm
## What a great way to say thank you to associates -- cold, hard cash!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 18, 2021 at 1:00 PMJune 18, 2021 at 12:44 PM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/katten-raises/&text=New%20Raises%20Are%20Like%20Catnip%20For%20Associates%20At%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/katten-raises/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/katten-raises/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Look what the cat dragged in — another Biglaw firm raising associate salaries!

The latest firm to increase compensation for hard-working associates is Katten Muchin Rosenman, a firm ranking 67th on the most recent Am Law 100 with $646,601,000 in gross revenue last year. And they’re showing they know what it takes to keep and attract quality attorneys: lots of money.

The firm is matching the scale set by Davis Polk, well, at least through the class of 2014. The new compensation grid, effective July 1, is as follows:

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Raises) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Raises”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# Wachtell's New Co-Chairs Likely To Stay The Course With Their Leadership Style
## If it ain't broke, don't fix it -- and Wachtell certainly isn't broken.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 20, 2023 at 4:13 PMNovember 20, 2023 at 4:11 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/wachtells-new-co-chairs-likely-to-stay-the-course-with-their-leadership-style/&text=Wachtell’s%20New%20Co-Chairs%20Likely%20To%20Stay%20The%20Course%20With%20Their%20Leadership%20Style)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/wachtells-new-co-chairs-likely-to-stay-the-course-with-their-leadership-style/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/wachtells-new-co-chairs-likely-to-stay-the-course-with-their-leadership-style/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

It works until it doesn’t, and I don’t mean that in a negative way. They don’t have a lot of partners leaving for other firms. They bring people up, some make partner, and they stay there for large portions of their careers. They are in a unique position.

— Jon Truster, a New York law firm recruiter and a partner at Macrae, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/11/20/wachtell-seeks-balance-between-continuity-and-change/) on Wachtell’s steady approach amid a [change in leadership](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/wachtells-co-chairs-step-down-after-17-years-ushering-in-new-leaders/) after nearly two decades. Andrew Nussbaum, a corporate partner, and William Savitt, co-chair of the firm’s litigation department, will [take the reins](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/wachtells-co-chairs-step-down-after-17-years-ushering-in-new-leaders/) at the elite firm, and will likely maintain the traditional approach their predecessors took in leading the firm.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# The Critical Need For Pro Bono Immigration Work
## Substantial attention is needed to deliver fairness to those who soon are to need it the most.
By David Lash  
onDecember 1, 2016 at 3:59 PMDecember 15, 2016 at 12:27 PM
43
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/the-critical-need-for-pro-bono-immigration-work/&text=The%20Critical%20Need%20For%20Pro%20Bono%20Immigration%20Work)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/the-critical-need-for-pro-bono-immigration-work/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/the-critical-need-for-pro-bono-immigration-work/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Any pending increase in immigration deportation proceedings will require an uptick in vigilance, a rededication to due process and fairness. Democracy has to step-up. Those who are vulnerable, who face removal from the United States, who are at risk of returning to dangerous and uncertain futures in a home country from which they fled, are entitled to our democracy’s historic promises.

Regardless of politics, the laws as currently written entitle immigrants to certain rights when their fates are in the hands of the judicial system. Regardless of politics, many of those facing possible removal are entitled to be here, to find the safety they risked their lives to reach. But those promises mean almost nothing unless democracy serves the people who need it most urgently. And the judicial system, simply, will not work unless those in it have lawyers to represent them. For that to happen, several crucial steps must be taken.

First, the particular realities of millions have to be acknowledged. They are not dangerous felons, rather they are terrified children, mothers, and families who were assaulted, left widowed and orphaned by brutal violence, raped, extorted, kidnapped, threatened in countries where law enforcement was either unable or unwilling to help them. They risked their lives to escape, enduring horror on a journey with no certain outcome. Many are children, fleeing alone. Many are mothers and young children, frightened and running for their lives. Others still are families, leaving behind all they knew for the chance to live safely together. Many of the children are eligible to remain in the United States and be granted Special Immigrant Juvenile Status. Many more are eligible for asylum. Most do not speak English, all are terrified, none can navigate a complex system of justice and laws in a language they do not understand.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Second, even though the laws may entitle them to be in this country lawfully, virtually none are entitled to have a lawyer appointed to represent them. In recent years, 70 percent of all who face deportation do not have attorneys. Almost half of them were ordered deported at their very first court hearings. However, of those who managed to find representation, only 4 percent were ordered to be removed at that early stage. Only one in 15 families without lawyers were even able to file the correct papers with the court. With the advent of the so-called “rocket dockets” that were instituted to deal with the women and children crossing the U.S./Mexico border, the need for lawyers has become only more critical.

Third, the overwhelming need for attorneys requires an overwhelming need for the private bar to volunteer their pro bono services, be trained, and represent, as a community, as many clients as they possibly can. More than 500,000 cases are pending in the immigration courts. Increased enforcement will put the system further and further behind. There are as many as 750,000 recipients of temporary status and work permits under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrival program whose protections may soon be reversed. Although many lawyers and law firms already have increased their pro bono activities, tens of thousands more will be needed. The usual suspects will not be enough. The big firms, the immigration practitioners, the many other solid volunteers from throughout the legal community already are doing their part. Efforts to delve far deeper into the private bar, to solicit many more new volunteers, must be made by bar associations, elected officials, legal aid organizations, and anyone else who can help.

Fourth, and most important, substantial funding for legal services organizations must immediately be found and infused into a service delivery system that already is stretched beyond capacity. The efforts of the private bar to provide support can go only as far as the shoulders of the legal aid community can carry them. Pro bono volunteers need to be trained. Critically, they need to be supervised and mentored by expert practitioners. Cases need to be screened and evaluated by experienced immigration attorneys. Clients need to be systematically interviewed, analyzed and referred in an effective and thorough manner. This complex process can only be accomplished if our country’s legal aid organizations have the funding they need to significantly ramp up, expand their expertise, grow their capacity, create more leverage through their pro bono efforts, and maintain their quality.

The promise of our democracy is built on the effectiveness of the judicial system. It is the most directly responsive branch of government, the arm of our Constitution that ensures liberty and justice. Substantial attention is needed to deliver fairness to those who soon are to need it the most. Politics do not matter. The law demands nothing else.

# Associate Bonus And New Partner Watch: Susman Godfrey
## Bonuses are down a little from last year, but they're still great, and the new partner class is large.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onDecember 13, 2016 at 1:54 PMJune 8, 2017 at 2:28 PM
88
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associate-bonus-and-new-partner-watch-susman-godfrey/&text=Associate%20Bonus%20And%20New%20Partner%20Watch:%20Susman%20Godfrey)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associate-bonus-and-new-partner-watch-susman-godfrey/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associate-bonus-and-new-partner-watch-susman-godfrey/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
On the evening of December 1, the place to be for New York litigators was the [Susman Godfrey](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/susman-godfrey/) holiday party. The food — catered by Daniel Boulud, who flew back from Tokyo to personally oversee the preparations — was fantastic, as always. The drink flowed liberally. The setting — the firm’s first year in its spectacular new offices — was better than ever. (The crisis of the evening: a shortage of olives at the bar, presumably due to excessive martini consumption.)

It’s not surprising that the firm was in a celebratory mood. Susman Godfrey once again had a strong year, reflected in bountiful bonuses. As reported by [Vivia Chen of The Careerist](http://www.americanlawyer.com/home/id=1202774537053/Susmans-Santa-Bonuses-Up-to-140K-and-Designer-Canapeacutes?mcode=1202617075486&curindex=0&slreturn=20161113121437):

Associates who’ve been at the firm six years are bagging a minimum of $120,000 in bonus, maxing out at $140,000 for those who’ve put in super long hours. That’s a $20,000 to $40,000 surplus over what Cravath, Swaine & Moore, which sets the industry standard, is paying its most senior associates (graduates of 2009 and earlier years).

Out-paying Cravath (and all other major firms) to get prized associates has long been a Susman strategy. But unlike Cravath, Susman pays out bonuses based on length of service at the firm rather than class year. Here’s the bonus scale at Susman:

Six years at firm:
$120,000 to $140,000 bonus (verus $100,000 for class year 2009 and earlier at Cravath).

Five years at firm:
$105,000 minimum ($90,000 for class of 2010 at Cravath).

Four years at firm:
$95,000 minimum ($80,000 for class of 2011 at Cravath).

Three years at firm:
$85,000 minimum ($65,000 for class of 2012 at Cravath).

Two years at firm:
$65,000 minimum ($50,000 for class of 2013 at Cravath).

One year at firm:
$40,000 minimum ($25,000 for class of 2014 at Cravath).

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The class of 2014 is the relevant comparison for people who have been at Susman Godfrey for a year because the firm requires everyone to complete at least one clerkship (and many Susman Godfrey lawyers do two or more, including Supreme Court clerkships).

It is true, as noted by Chen, that these bonuses are down a little from [last year](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/associate-bonus-watch-susman-godfrey-are-these-the-best-bonuses-of-the-season/). The top bonus in 2016 was $140,000, compared to $165,000 in 2015, and the lowest bonus in 2016 was $40,000, compared to $55,000 in 2015. [Bill Carmody](http://www.susmangodfrey.com/attorneys/bill-carmody/), head of the firm’s New York office, explained that this year wasn’t quite as good as last year for the firm. But even at these lower levels, Susman Godfrey bonuses are still way above the market scale (ranging from $15,000 to $100,000).

Furthermore, Susman Godfrey associates don’t have to worry as much about their bonuses because they are partners before they know it. “It’s a seven-year track,” Bill Carmody explained, “and since most everyone clerks for two years, that means you only have to be here for five years to be partner.”

UPDATE (6/8/2017, 2:27 p.m.): A clarification: one year of clerking gets counted against the track, but the second year of credit goes just to Supreme Court clerks.

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Which brings us to Susman Godfrey’s new partners. The firm elevated seven out of the eight associates up for consideration (with office location and law school noted parenthetically): Matt Behncke (Houston / Texas 2009), Amanda Bonn (Los Angeles / Stanford 2009), Jordan Connors (Seattle / Columbia 2008), John Lahad (Houston / Houston 2009), Oleg Elkhunovich (Los Angeles / Penn 2009), Weston O’Black (Houston 2008 / Houston), and Steven Shepard (New York / Yale 2007).

The new partners — one of the firm’s largest classes, according to Carmody — exhibit geographic diversity, with at least one lawyer coming from each of the firm’s four offices. They are a bit short on gender and racial or ethnic diversity — one woman, six white men — but as we’ve chronicled in these pages, Susman Godfrey is [far](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/sullivan-cromwells-new-partners-impressive-yes-diverse-not-so-much/) from [alone](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/cleary-gottliebs-new-partner-class-where-are-the-women/) on that front. (Also, given the firm’s small size — it has around 114 lawyers in total — one could argue that achieving demographic diversity presents more of a challenge for SG compared to its Biglaw brethren.)

Congratulations to Susman Godfrey’s seven new partners, and congrats to its associates — i.e., its future partners — on the fantastic bonuses.

# Am Law 100 Firm Finally Decides To Offer Special Bonuses To Associates
## But they're tied to billable hours.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 20, 2021 at 10:30 AMJanuary 20, 2021 at 10:32 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/am-law-100-firm-finally-decides-to-offer-special-bonuses-to-associates/&text=Am%20Law%20100%20Firm%20Finally%20Decides%20To%20Offer%20Special%20Bonuses%20To%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/am-law-100-firm-finally-decides-to-offer-special-bonuses-to-associates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/am-law-100-firm-finally-decides-to-offer-special-bonuses-to-associates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Back in December, special bonuses reigned supreme as a part of Biglaw firms’ year-end bonuses; after all, associates had worked themselves to the bone through the repeated vagaries of the pandemic, and this extra cash served as a way to thank them for their many sacrifices. The vast majority of firms offered these special bonuses without hourly requirements, but quite a few did tie them to billables, and some firms opted not to offer special bonuses at all.

As can be imagined, associates at those firms were [quite angry](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/sheppard-bonuses/); not only was their work not being rewarded, but their bonuses were officially below market. One firm that originally refused to offer special bonuses recently announced that appreciation money was officially in play.

The firm in question is Sheppard Mullin, and while more money is now on the table for associates, the additional bonus compensation is being offered on a sliding scale based on billable hours. Check out the firm’s scale, below:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  


As you can see, the firm is offering the prevailing market rate special bonuses to associates who have billed 2,000 hours. Associates who billed 1,900 hours will receive half that amount, while those who billed 1,950 hours will receive a bit more. This may not be the market standard for special bonuses, but hopefully this is enough to assauge associates at the firm.

All bonuses at Sheppard Mullin will be paid out on January 22.

(Flip to the next page to see the Sheppard Mullin special bonus memo.)

# Biglaw Associates Are Probably Working In Smaller Offices Than Before
## Smaller office spaces for attorneys are apparently the way of the future.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 8, 2024 at 4:14 PMJanuary 8, 2024 at 3:10 PM
16
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/biglaw-associates-are-probably-working-in-smaller-offices-than-before/&text=Biglaw%20Associates%20Are%20Probably%20Working%20In%20Smaller%20Offices%20Than%20Before)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/biglaw-associates-are-probably-working-in-smaller-offices-than-before/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/biglaw-associates-are-probably-working-in-smaller-offices-than-before/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

Now you’re seeing lawyer offices at 150 square feet. The office is becoming a place for heads-down work [instead of meetings].

— Thomas Fulcher, chair of the legal tenant practice group at Savills, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2024/01/08/more-law-firms-in-new-york-opt-for-larger-spaces/) on the shrinking office sizes that lawyers can expect to see, down from an average around 225-250 square feet per attorney. Biglaw firms in New York, however, have been expanding their office footprints. “If you have more attorneys, you’re going to need more space,” he said.

# First Impressions Are Worth Millions For Summers. Here’s How To Get Yours Right.
## A practical, no-nonsense guide to being a memorable summer associate — the good kind of memorable.
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onMay 12, 2022 at 3:15 PMAugust 1, 2022 at 1:04 PM
20
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/first-impressions-are-worth-millions-for-summers-heres-how-to-get-yours-right/&text=First%20Impressions%20Are%20Worth%20Millions%20For%20Summers.%20Here’s%20How%20To%20Get%20Yours%20Right.)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/first-impressions-are-worth-millions-for-summers-heres-how-to-get-yours-right/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/first-impressions-are-worth-millions-for-summers-heres-how-to-get-yours-right/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[](https://info.abovethelaw.com/en-us/sixteen-ways-for-summer-associates)You know that shiver that runs down your spine when the words “based on a true story” come up?

Well, it turns out that those shivers are not just for horror movies and true-crime podcasts.

Our friends at [Kinney Recruiting](https://www.kinneyrecruiting.com/) share the best (and therefore worst) summer associate stories they have heard, seen, or lived through in a section of the free eBook, “16 Ways To Not F**k Up Your Summer Associate Experience.”

[Download the book](https://info.abovethelaw.com/en-us/sixteen-ways-for-summer-associates) for their stories — and for tips, tricks, and guidelines that will help you succeed.

By filling out the form, you are opting in to receive communication from Above the Law and its Partners.

# Solicitor General's Office Is Loading Up On Biglaw Hires
## The game of musical chairs is nearing its end.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 31, 2017 at 10:48 AMAugust 31, 2017 at 9:48 AM
52
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/solicitor-generals-office-is-loading-up-on-biglaw-hires/&text=Solicitor%20General’s%20Office%20Is%20Loading%20Up%20On%20Biglaw%20Hires)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/solicitor-generals-office-is-loading-up-on-biglaw-hires/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/solicitor-generals-office-is-loading-up-on-biglaw-hires/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Chris Michel, Frederick Liu and Michael Huston

It’s been a busy season at the Solicitor General’s office. The summer has been characterized as a “[game of musical chairs](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/whats-going-on-at-the-solicitor-generals-office/?rf=1)” with attorneys moving in and out of the office. Now comes word that the office has made a trio of Biglaw hires — and not a moment too soon, they have about a month to prepare before the start of the October Supreme Court term.

Frederick Liu, partner at Hogan Lovells, Christopher Michel, associate at Kirkland & Ellis, and Michael Huston, associate at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher are all moving to the Solicitor General’s office in the position of assistant to the SG, and that’s not all they have in common. The three have all clerked for Chief Justice John Roberts.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
As Law.com [reports](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/08/30/solicitor-generals-office-fills-ranks-with-big-law-hires/), high-profile positions in the SG office routinely lead to even bigger and brighter things in the future:

“Assistant to the SG is one of the best jobs an appellate lawyer can have. I don’t think that’s changed at all,” said Joseph Palmore of Morrison & Foerster, who left the SG’s office in 2014 to co-chair the firm’s Supreme Court and appellate practice. A several-year tour of duty as an assistant to the SG can often become a launching pad for a return to law firms as leaders of appellate practices.

These hires complete the staff of 16 at the assistant level. Since it’s expected to be a [particularly noteworthy term](https://www.economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/08/swing-time), the hires are essential for the office. Now, if they could only get the head of the office confirmed… (Noel Francisco, Donald Trump’s pick for Solicitor General was formally nominated on March 7th, but has not, as of yet, gotten the official nod from Senate.)

# Sound Off: What Is *The* Worst Law?
## Not all laws are created equal.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 22, 2023 at 12:46 PMDecember 22, 2023 at 11:57 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/sound-off-what-is-the-worst-law/&text=Sound%20Off:%20What%20Is%20*The*%20Worst%20Law?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/sound-off-what-is-the-worst-law/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/sound-off-what-is-the-worst-law/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As lawyers, we’re obliged to uphold the law…. but that doesn’t always mean you agree with it. Attorneys are in a unique position to know the underbelly of the system of laws that govern our society.

So, we want to know, what is *the* worst law?

Perhaps it’s the fact that qualified immunity — the doctrine that lets police get away with pretty much everything — was a [goddamn scrivener’s error](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/police-can-legally-set-you-on-fire-because-someone-in-the-1800s-made-a-copying-error/). And what about the [immunity of the gun industry](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/the-law-the-needs-to-be-repealed-immediately-to-bring-gun-makers-to-heel/)? That only makes the American gun problem worse. Maybe it’s the[ injustice of the felony murder](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/it-looks-like-sotomayor-is-1-of-3-supreme-court-justices-who-actually-believes-the-whole-do-the-crime-do-the-time-thing/) rule? Speaking of injustice, maybe [mandatory minimums](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/scotus-plays-hell-with-congressional-intent-in-mandatory-minimums-case/) infuriate you. Let’s not get started on the [dumb immigration laws](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/why-does-the-doj-prosecute-20000-people-a-year-for-immigration-crimes/). We’ve all witnessed the wild results the [electoral college yields](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/why-is-the-electoral-college-constitutional/). Or maybe you’re annoyed by the simple power grabs like towns putting an [age limit on trick or treating](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/you-are-too-old-to-trick-or-treat-like-by-law/).

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
This is your opportunity to sound off on the absolute dumbest laws out there. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Dumb%20Laws) or text us (646-820-8477) your nominations for the dumbest laws. Once we have our slate of dumb law nominees, we’ll hold a poll to crown the dumbest law in all the land. Bonus: the “winner” law may be featured in [Above the Law alum](https://abovethelaw.com/author/elie-mystal/)/justice correspondent for The Nation magazine/author of [Allow Me To Retort: A Black Guy’s Guide to the Constitution ](https://amzn.to/3GmqiXe)(affiliate link) Elie Mystal’s new book, “Bad Laws.”

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter [@Kathryn1](%E2%80%9C//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22%E2%80%9D) or Mastodon @Kathryn1@mastodon.social.

# Biglaw Partner In Hot Water After Twitter Outburst Inspired By Kavanaugh Hearing
## Cursing out women isn't a great idea when you're supposed to be a professional.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 1, 2018 at 12:32 PMOctober 4, 2018 at 7:57 AM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/biglaw-partner-in-hot-water-after-twitter-outburst-inspired-by-kavanaugh-hearing/&text=Biglaw%20Partner%20In%20Hot%20Water%20After%20Twitter%20Outburst%20Inspired%20By%20Kavanaugh%20Hearing)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/biglaw-partner-in-hot-water-after-twitter-outburst-inspired-by-kavanaugh-hearing/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/biglaw-partner-in-hot-water-after-twitter-outburst-inspired-by-kavanaugh-hearing/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Frank Aquila

The awfulness of the Brett Kavanaugh hearings has touched us all. Some people have turned to friends or political activism to cope with the emotional turmoil that the mockery of our judicial branch stirred up. Others took to Twitter to release their rage. In that respect mergers and acquisitions partner at Sullivan & Cromwell [Frank Aquila](https://www.sullcrom.com/lawyers/FrancisJ-Aquila) is like a lot of us, but his social media rant went the extra mile and got him in some hot water.

It started when Sarah Huckabee Sanders used the official @PressSec Twitter account to exalt Lindsey Graham’s angry shock that people somehow care that a potential lifetime appointee has been credibly accused of sexual assault. But instead of expressing disgust in the privacy of his own corner office, Aquila took to Twitter, which would have been fine, except for the misogynistic language he used. Yeah, telling a woman — no matter how vile her opinions — to “Rot in Hell You B!tch” isn’t a good look when you’re trying to express your support for victims of sexual assault.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  


Once the tweet started going viral, as Law.com [reports](https://www.law.com/newyorklawjournal/2018/09/28/sullivan-cromwell-partner-apologies-for-rot-in-hell-tweet-after-kavanaugh-hearings/), Aquila deleted his account. And as part of the apology tour he’s subjected himself to, Aquila sent around a firm-wide email on Friday, calling his tweet “inappropriate and hurtful”:

Last evening, I responded to a tweet from Sarah Sanders in an inappropriate and hurtful manner. Clearly my emotions got the best of me, but equally clearly neither Ms. Sanders nor any woman should be subjected to such animus. I take full responsibility for my ‎actions and I sincerely apologize to Ms. Sanders.

Aquila’s outrage is certainly understandable — a lot of people feel similarly. But cursing out women isn’t a great idea when you’re supposed to be a professional.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)

# More Lawyers Should Take The Final Week Of The Year Off
## The amount of work, much like the amount of daylight, can be pretty thin at the end of December. Use that to your advantage.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onDecember 27, 2023 at 2:02 PMDecember 27, 2023 at 12:47 PM
8
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/more-lawyers-should-take-the-final-week-of-the-year-off/&text=More%20Lawyers%20Should%20Take%20The%20Final%20Week%20Of%20The%20Year%20Off)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/more-lawyers-should-take-the-final-week-of-the-year-off/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/more-lawyers-should-take-the-final-week-of-the-year-off/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
During the year, many attorneys have court appearances and other commitments that make it extremely difficult for them to take any real vacation. However, one of the best times for lawyers to take off from work for a long vacation is the end of the year due to the natural slowdown. Nevertheless, in my own experience, it seems like fewer people than usual are taking time off at year’s end despite the benefits.

Earlier in my career, I worked at a law firm that paid attorneys and staff modest salaries. In exchange, the law firm offered a number of nonmonetary benefits, which included letting employees actually take weeks off for vacation each year without judgments or questions. While working at that firm, I decided to take the last two weeks of the year off entirely, as did many others at the firm. There were fewer disadvantages to taking this period off than other days in the year.

I did not travel anywhere during this time off, but the vacation was amazing. In a similar vein to the film “Office Space,” I basically did nothing, [and it was everything I thought it could be](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6AiGNL0LYN0). I focused on hobbies more than I was able to during other periods of the year, and I caught up on all of the movies and television shows that interested me.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The experience had a positive impact on my outlook when I finally returned to work. Having enjoyed the holidays to the fullest since I did not need to think about work responsibilities, I was able to interact with family and friends in ways that were not possible at other points of the year. Since I was able to recharge my batteries, I was also in a solid position to complete work tasks when I finally returned to work in the new year.

Even though the end of the year is naturally a good time to take off from work, people may refuse. Some attorneys and staff like to take performative steps to show supervisors that they are dedicated to a job even though these steps may not impact the bottom line for employers. Showing up to work around the holidays is one such performative step, and if you are early in your career, or are on thin ice at work, I can understand the strategy. Indeed, shortly after starting a new job once, I showed up to the office on President’s Day — even though most attorneys and staff did not — for the express purpose of showing my new employer that I was dedicated to my job.

However, a career is a marathon and not a sprint, and in most circumstances, people have no good reason to be at an office around the holidays. More people should embrace a long time off from work toward the end of the year to recharge their batteries and take advantage of the natural slowdown of this time of year. This can have a number of personal benefits that can also make an employee even more effective when they return to work in the new year.

# Associate Bonus Watch: More Word From The West Coast
## People are generally happy, although individual numbers remain to be communicated.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onFebruary 13, 2017 at 3:45 PM
4
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/associate-bonus-watch-more-word-from-the-west-coast/&text=Associate%20Bonus%20Watch:%20More%20Word%20From%20The%20West%20Coast)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/associate-bonus-watch-more-word-from-the-west-coast/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/associate-bonus-watch-more-word-from-the-west-coast/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The California-founded firms — note that careful phrasing, to reflect how they are now national, even global, enterprises — are announcing associate bonuses. Last week, we reported on bonus news from [Cooley](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/associate-bonus-watch-no-memo-no-problem/) and [Morrison & Foerster](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/associate-bonus-watch-mo-money-at-mofo/).

Late last week, associates at [O’Melveny & Myers](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/omelveny-myers/) also learned their financial fate. Associates received a voicemail — the firm’s standard mode for communicating compensation-related news, such as last summer’s [pay raise](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/money_on_the_west_coast/) — explaining what to expect:

- Associates meeting the firm’s expectations regarding quality and productivity (informally, around 1900-1950 hours) will receive a standard bonus.
- The standard bonuses follow the [market aka Cravath scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/associate-bonus-watch-cravath-announces-its-2016-associate-bonuses/) (although the voicemail did not refer to it in that way; instead, it just announced the various amounts for each class year).
- The firm will make upward adjustments to bonuses for factors including, but not limited to, quality, productivity, and citizenship.
- There was no mention of any below-market bonuses.
- Bonuses will be included in the last paycheck for February.
- Associates will learn of their individual bonus amounts in their reviews, which are now underway and should conclude before the end of the month.
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Reactions could change depending on how those individual reviews go — OMM associates, you know [where to reach us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=OMM%20Bonuses) — but for now, O’Melveny associates are (mostly) content:

- “Folks are happy with the announcement, but we’ll see how the mood will be once everyone gets their individual bonus numbers.”
- “I’d say we all just expected this. No one has been complaining, as far as I’ve heard.”
- “Partners are expected to communicate individual bonuses in reviews, which are just starting, so no real sense of reactions just yet beyond being generally pleased that we matched.”
- “The overall scale is welcome news…. I have not yet had my meeting, so I can’t really comment on my reaction just yet. I do, however, think it’s ridiculous that it takes them this long to announce and pay out the bonuses.”
- “There’s some confusion over what one exactly needs to do to hit bonus — informally, hours cutoff is 1950, but I’ve heard that there is some flexibility on that number, possibly based on how busy it was for individual groups.”
As for the upward adjustments or above-market bonuses, it’s not clear how large they are. As one source of ours said, “I don’t know of any specific amounts given above scale. I don’t think I would want to work enough to find out.”

Fair enough. Extra cash is nice, but you know what else is nice? Working in Biglaw and still having a life. And that seems possible at OMM, which according to Vault offers the [best quality of life](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/the-best-law-firms-to-work-for-biglaw-quality-of-life-rankings/) among large law firms.

Bonus season is winding down, but it’s not yet over — so please help us help you. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# This Biglaw Firm's Wall Street Roots Go Deep
## The firm is still going strong downtown.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 1, 2019 at 5:45 PMAugust 1, 2019 at 4:16 PM
0

# Let’s All Watch Dewey & LeBoeuf Burn. Again.
## Dewey remember this story?
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 1, 2022 at 10:30 AMAugust 1, 2022 at 9:26 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/lets-all-watch-dewey-leboeuf-burn-again/&text=Let’s%20All%20Watch%20Dewey%20&%20LeBoeuf%20Burn.%20Again.)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/lets-all-watch-dewey-leboeuf-burn-again/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/lets-all-watch-dewey-leboeuf-burn-again/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The aughts were a WILD time. It wasn’t all boy bands and butterfly clips, no, it was also the largest financial collapse since the Great Depression. Good times!

Sure, everyone’s talking about a recession these days, but it ain’t got nuttin’ on the ’08 era. The housing market collapsed, Lehman Brothers went under, and a 100+-year-old Biglaw firm declared bankruptcy.

For those who worked in Biglaw at the time, of course you know I’m talking about Dewey & LeBoeuf. It started as a mega merger of two venerable law firms and ended with 1,000+ attorneys out of work, bankruptcy court, and criminal charges. Above the Law came of age in that era, breathlessly reporting on all the drama as it happened —- and there was so much to say.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Now Bloomberg Law has a new documentary detailing how it all went so wrong.

Watch the trailer below and remember: no matter how absurd Biglaw seems right now, there was a time when it was a whole lot worse.

# Biglaw Associate Passes Away Following The Birth Of Son
## She's described as a 'bright light' who will be missed.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 3, 2021 at 12:43 PMNovember 4, 2021 at 8:00 AM
15
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/biglaw-associate-passes-away-following-the-birth-of-son/&text=Biglaw%20Associate%20Passes%20Away%20Following%20The%20Birth%20Of%20Son)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/biglaw-associate-passes-away-following-the-birth-of-son/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/biglaw-associate-passes-away-following-the-birth-of-son/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Sad news for the legal community — it’s been reported that McGuireWoods associate Lauren Graff died on October 30th. Graff suffered a pulmonary embolism while pregnant and passed away after giving birth to a son, James Rolland Graff-Ness. She is survived by her spouse, Mitchell Ness, [who works ](https://www.linkedin.com/in/mitchell-ness-80885190/)at the Illinois Attorney General’s office.

The firm offered the [following statement](https://www.mcguirewoods.com/people/g/lauren-m-graff) on Graff’s passing:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Our colleague and friend Lauren Graff passed away on Oct. 30, 2021. An associate with the firm’s Corporate & Private Equity Department, Lauren tirelessly served her clients and was dedicated to community service and children’s causes. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her.

Graff and Ness both attended the University of Minnesota Law School, and Dean Garry Jenkins [offered](https://law.umn.edu/news/2021-10-31-minnesota-law-mourns-passing-lauren-graff-19) the following words:

“Please join me in offering our heartfelt condolences to Mitchell, baby James, and Lauren’s family,” said Dean Garry W. Jenkins in a message to the Minnesota Law community. “Lauren touched the lives of so many in our community and this is a heartbreaking loss.”

Professor Emily Buchholz also said Graff was an up-and-coming legal talent:

Lauren was kind, thoughtful, and a natural leader,” Buchholz recalled. “During group discussions, she was always willing to share her perspective, which was a blend of pragmatism and common sense on the one hand and sharp intellectual insight and deep knowledge on the other hand. She had a way of amplifying the perspectives of those around her either by acknowledging their contributions directly or by modeling assertive, yet respectful and humble participation. The best lawyers are often the best people and Lauren was well on her way to becoming a star attorney at McGuireWoods, I have no doubt about it. Losing her is a blow to us all. She was a bright light who made the room better just by being in it.”

A[ GoFundMe](https://www.gofundme.com/f/graff-ness?qid=f8bdd33e06ca81f0f2f08d91379ed3e0) has been set up in support of Graff’s family. Our condolences to her family, friends, and colleagues.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# Morning Docket: 09.28.17
## * Federal law enforcement's crackdown on NCAA coaches has likely brought an end to Rick Pitino's career. That said, we thought his career was over when we all learned that Louisville hired hookers for recruits so maybe he still has a shot. [[ESPN](http://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/20835496/louisville-coach-rick-pitino-find-way-trouble)] * Law firm mergers continue at a record place. Yep, there's [no fundamental market weakness](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/why-these-global-100-numbers-should-scare-the-bejeezus-out-of-you/) here at all. [[Am Law Daily](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202799104824/Law-Firm-Mergers-Keep-Record-Pace-in-Third-Quarter/)] * DOJ lawyers face an unpleasant grilling at the Second Circuit. Maybe someday Sessions can disinvite judges he doesn't want criticizing his unsupported legal theories. [[Slate](http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2017/09/the_doj_s_new_anti_gay_legal_posture_just_got_shut_down_in_federal_court.html)] * Women losing pregnancies while detained by the administration. I'd say we're going to look back on this era of immigration policy in horror, but we can probably go ahead and be horrified now. [[Huffington Post](http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/immigrant-detention-pregnancy_us_59cbaee4e4b05063fe0e211b/)] * The USD Alumni Board has weighed in on the [Wax/Alexander op-ed](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/law-professors-say-white-50s-culture-is-superior-other-racist-stuff/). They take a "let's all come together" approach, which isn't wrong as much as it seems asymmetric. When one-side throws bombs about cultural superiority, decrying divisiveness puts the onus on the wrong side side to move. [[Motions Online](http://www.motionsonline.org/2017/09/27/letter-from-the-alumni-board/)] * The most likely grants from the long conference. [[Empirical SCOTUS](https://empiricalscotus.com/2017/09/27/petitions-long-conference/)] * Here's how you get $4 billion in punitive damages (hint: be in Texas). [[Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/09/27/litigators-of-the-week-how-3-dallas-lawyers-nailed-jpmorgan-chase-with-4-billion-in-punitive-damages/)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 28, 2017 at 8:13 AM
0

# Looks Like Another Biglaw Firm Opts To Defer Incoming Associates Until Next Year
## Involuntary vacations abound.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 23, 2023 at 2:21 PMJune 23, 2023 at 1:07 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/looks-like-another-biglaw-firm-opts-to-defer-incoming-associates-until-next-year/&text=Looks%20Like%20Another%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Opts%20To%20Defer%20Incoming%20Associates%20Until%20Next%20Year)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/looks-like-another-biglaw-firm-opts-to-defer-incoming-associates-until-next-year/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/looks-like-another-biglaw-firm-opts-to-defer-incoming-associates-until-next-year/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Layoffs continue to be mostly contained to firms with tech-heavy portfolios and a few additional outliers sorting out overleveraging in some practice areas. But if you thought “avoiding layoffs” meant a firm wasn’t feeling the deal slowdown pinch… Well, denial ain’t just a river in Egypt.

Because defer ain’t [just a river in Saskatchewan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fir_River). The deferral taboo has been broken and whether firms are [pushing off everyone](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/after-layoffs-last-year-cooley-delays-start-date-for-first-year-associates/) or [just some practice groups](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/perkins-coie-is-the-next-firm-to-defer-incoming-associates/), asking the incoming class to cool its heels for an extended period is the trendy way to save on some expenses before deal volume returns.

A tipster informs us that another firm has joined the deferral ranks, deferring all first years across the country until January 15, 2024. As far as we can tell, the firm is offering a $15K stipend (“less applicable taxes” as the tipster notes) and no health coverage. We reached out to the firm for comment but have not heard back at this time.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
The market appears to be coalescing around a $15K stipend for deferral — with the exception of Cooley’s special offer to some associates willing [to defer to 2025 for a $100K price](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/cooley-deferral-corporate-associates/). Assuming a September start date that’s the equivalent of a $45K-50K annual salary. Which isn’t bad, assuming the incoming class hasn’t lined up real estate in New York or San Francisco beginning in September.

If they have, then it’s probably time to start making choices between food and shelter. Just what people need to heap on top of studying for the bar!

If your firm or organization is reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through deferrals, open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs) or text us ([646-820-8477](tel:646-820-8477)). Thanks!

# 'HIV-Positive, Former DC Biglaw Attorney, Washed Out, Now Living In Midwest'
## He's putting his life back together, 'optimistic despite it all,' and willing to share his wisdom with others.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onJuly 24, 2017 at 6:42 PMJuly 25, 2017 at 1:13 PM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/hiv-positive-former-dc-biglaw-attorney-washed-out-now-living-in-midwest/&text=‘HIV-Positive,%20Former%20DC%20Biglaw%20Attorney,%20Washed%20Out,%20Now%20Living%20In%20Midwest’)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/hiv-positive-former-dc-biglaw-attorney-washed-out-now-living-in-midwest/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/hiv-positive-former-dc-biglaw-attorney-washed-out-now-living-in-midwest/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Basically, I grew up privileged, I had it all, was a really good lawyer until I burned out, and then I squandered it all, and THEN I got the HIV, and it was hard, and I’m stronger for it, but my life is very different now….

— An anonymous Biglaw alum, in an insightful and moving [‘Ask Me Anything’](https://www.reddit.com/r/casualiama/comments/6oz59k/hiv_former_dc_biglaw_attorney_washed_out_now/) (AMA) posted on Reddit over the weekend. He’s ‘putting [his] life back together,’ ‘optimistic despite it all,’ and willing to share his hard-earned wisdom with lawyers and law students struggling with depression, anxiety, substance abuse, and HIV/AIDS — all challenges he has confronted over the years.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

He previously worked as a federal prosecutor in Newark, New Jersey; a litigation associate at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz; and a law clerk to Judge Diarmuid F. O’Scannlain of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. You can connect with David on [Twitter (@DavidLat)](http://twitter.com/DavidLat), [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/davidlat), and [Facebook](http://facebook.com/DavidLat), and you can reach him by email at [dlat@abovethelaw.com](mailto:dlat@abovethelaw.com).
