# Power Niche Marketing: 6 More Things Not To Do
## A few more things that are almost certainly a waste of time in terms of business development (or, at the very least, not the best use of your time).
By [Bruce Stachenfeld](https://abovethelaw.com/author/brucestachenfeld/)  
onApril 27, 2017 at 2:28 PMApril 27, 2017 at 3:25 PM
31
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/power-niche-marketing-6-more-things-not-to-do/&text=Power%20Niche%20Marketing:%206%20More%20Things%20Not%20To%20Do)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/power-niche-marketing-6-more-things-not-to-do/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/power-niche-marketing-6-more-things-not-to-do/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Continuing from my [previous article](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/power-niche-marketing-6-things-not-to-do/), here are some more things that are almost certainly a waste of time in terms of business development (or, at the very least, not the best use of your time).

- Spending a ton of time writing a great article for publication.
There are two things that will likely happen here:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
First, you will be giving away your expertise and industry knowledge for free to your competition

Second, you will spend a great deal of your most precious resource – your time – for a very uncertain payoff.

Doing things like this make you “feel” like you are doing something useful, but sorry, you likely aren’t doing anything that will really help you.

Having said that, sometimes articles can be useful to establish your reputation and bona fides; however, overall it is not the most effective use of your time.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
I will give you, in a later column, a more useful way to write articles for publication.

- Advertising.
Of course advertising can potentially be a powerful technique for a major company that is trying to build its market share (e.g. “Things Go Better With Coca Cola”); however, for law firms (other than global law firms and regional powerhouses that are already a dominant player trying to extend that dominance), I think the dollars are better spent elsewhere.

- Brochures, Videos, Website, Your Bio, etc.
I am overall torn on brochures (get it?). There is a perfectly good argument that no one ever reads them so they are a complete waste of time. Yet, on the other hand, if they are well prepared they can put forth your message – maybe in just a few key words – on the cover, and in the call-out boxes (which people sometimes do look at), and they provide a modicum of seriousness and class to your enterprise. Although I am being a little wishy-washy here, I will say that ideally you will have a really nice-looking brochure that is very professionally prepared; however, I urge you to pull this off in a way that doesn’t take much of your precious asset of time.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Videos can be cool, and if they are unique, a bit crazy, and along the lines of a [Purple Cow](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/06/reinventing-the-law-business-blend-in-at-your-peril-you-need-to-stand-out/), and let you “put on a show” (which I will talk about in a later column), then I would say go for it. However, I would do everything I could to not spend that much time or money on it.

Of all these written materials, there is no question that the website is by far the most important thing you will write and where you should devote the most time. Third parties “always” go there to “check you out.” In this regard I advocate that it is key to have your website e interesting and not look like all the others. You want to stand out and make clear how different and unique you are — i.e., the heart of your message is you are a power player in your Power Niche.

It is the same with your online bio. Try to stand out and be different and make the same point about your power in your Power Niche. And don’t worry too much about mentioning every single thing you ever did in your career for fear that by omission you will lose out on customers and clients. It doesn’t work that way. Worry more about what you are saying than what you are not saying.

For all of these mediums, I advocate that you figure out your “message” before you write them up. It should be the same message in all of them. The message should be a short one. And the message should be about your power in your Power Niche.

- Direct Mail.
Today this is mostly by internet and is loosely called spam, and “spam” is hardly a compliment. Indeed, other than Monty Python’s [famous Spam skit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spam_(Monty_Python)), I haven’t ever heard anything positive about it.

I think spamming people is overall a terrible idea because it is such a turn-off and convinces people to ignore and avoid you as much as possible.

However, there is a way to cold call someone over the internet that can be done in a very classy manner, which I have used many times before, and which I will explain in a later column.

- Sponsorship of Cultural or Sporting Events.
Except for major law firms that find plain old advertising worthwhile, as I noted above, I don’t think this is worth it either. It is every expensive, plus time-consuming, and I don’t see what you get for it. Yes, your clients have a nice time, but I think if you took the time and the money and spent it as I otherwise advocate above, you will have a much more positive outcome.

By the way, this is very different from a one-on-one situation when you take a client out to a sporting event. That can be superb bonding time and very useful to building a relationship.

- Anything else that takes a ton of your time for an uncertain payoff is “probably” not worth it – unless the payoff is potentially enormous.
. . . .

If you have been doing any or all of the foregoing things, don’t bum out too much. I think I did every one of them, other than the social media stuff. The past is irrelevant – all that matters is what will happen going forward.

By the way, if you have done some of the foregoing and it has actually worked for you, consider why that is the case. Is it pure luck, in which event it is great that you were lucky but you still shouldn’t waste more time on it? Or, do you maybe have a special angle on the foregoing that I personally haven’t seen but is nonetheless successful that could be exploited?  I don’t like to admit it – but I don’t (yet) know everything….

Earlier: [Power Niche Marketing: 6 Things Not To Do](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/power-niche-marketing-6-things-not-to-do/)

[Bruce Stachenfeld](http://dsllp.com/attorneys/29/) is the managing partner of [Duval & Stachenfeld LLP](http://www.dsllp.com/), an approximately 70-lawyer law firm based in midtown Manhattan. The firm is known as “The Pure Play in Real Estate Law” because all of its practice areas are focused around real estate. ###More From Above the Law
[  ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
[Health Care / Medicine](https://abovethelaw.com/health-care-medicine/)
### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.

# Biglaw Firm Plans To Cut 5% Of Its Workforce, Including Attorneys
## The latest in Biglaw layoffs, and more than a dozen lawyers will be left jobless.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 14, 2023 at 11:12 AMAugust 14, 2023 at 5:00 PM
79
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/choate-layoffs-2023/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Plans%20To%20Cut%205%%20Of%20Its%20Workforce,%20Including%20Attorneys)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/choate-layoffs-2023/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/choate-layoffs-2023/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We hate to say it, but even though demand is slightly up, Biglaw’s [layoffs](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/layoffs/) show no sign of stopping.

The leaders of Choate Hall & Stewart — a firm that brought in $311,956,000 gross revenue in 2022, putting it at No. 119 in the most recent Am Law 200 — recently announced a reduction in force. The firm is cutting about 5% of its employees, including attorneys and business professionals. A source tells us that 17 associates are affected.

Although Choate was one of the Am Law 200 firms that made it into the top 20 for RPL in the American Lawyer’s latest rankings (No. 17, $1.61 million), it was also the only Am Law 200 firm to see a decline in RPL from the prior year (down 5.8%).

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Here’s an excerpt from the firm’s memo (available on the next page), citing “economic conditions” that have thwarted demand in certain practice areas as the reason behind these layoffs:

Despite our success, like our clients and major law firms generally, we live in a world which is impacted by general economic and market conditions. Reductions announced at many of our competitors during the last 6-12 months illustrate the challenges of the current economic environment. We have not been immune to them, and economic conditions have impacted work levels in certain parts of the Firm. After monitoring these developments carefully for a period of time, we have come to the difficult decision that we currently have too many lawyers and business professionals in certain practice areas and departments based on the current demands of our clients.

Bill Gelnaw and Charles Cheever, the firm’s co-managing partners, noted in the memo that the reduction in force “is a difficult step for Choate and one we deeply regret is necessary.”

Choate’s firmwide memo announcing the reduction in force is a kinder, gentler version of the layoff memos we’ve seen in the past. “The reduction is not a reflection on any of these individuals,” Gelnaw and Cheever wrote. “It is the result of work levels, not performance.” The memo continues, explaining that all those affected will receive severance packages and outplacement services from the firm.

# Morning Docket: 11.16.18
## * After delaying the decision, Judge Tim Kelly will be releasing his ruling in CNN's First Amendment case at 10 a.m. Is it lawful to revoke a reporter's press pass after an argument with the president? We'll soon find out. [[USA Today](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2018/11/15/judge-rule-friday-cnn-white-house-credential/2014447002/)] * "[W]e’re not going to leave any judges behind over these next two months." According to Senator Tom Cotton, the Senate is apparently planning to work through Christmas and New Year's Eve to confirm all of President Trump's judicial nominees in an effort to head off any obstruction by the Democrats. [[Washington Times](https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2018/nov/14/gop-confirm-trump-judicial-picks-through-christmas/)] * "I’m not trying to be rude. I can see your résumé. You’re a rock star." Despite her strong résumé, Allison Jones Rushing, the 36-year-old Fourth Circuit nominee, was repeatedly questioned by the Judiciary Committee about her "life experience" -- or lack thereof, since she graduated from law school 11 years ago. [[National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/2018/11/15/democrats-pressed-36-year-old-circuit-pick-on-life-experience/)] * What is David Boies planning for his next act? Is retirement on the table? He and the other name partners at Boies Schiller Flexner have apparently "been planning succession for 15 years." He said if he retired today, "the firm would be in good shape," but he thinks he "still [has] some things to contribute." [[New York Law Journal](https://www.law.com/newyorklawjournal/2018/11/15/after-fall-from-grace-david-boies-plots-next-battle/)] * Stormy Daniels says that while the "serious and obviously very troubling" domestic violence allegations against her lawyer Michael Avenatti are "only allegations" and that she'll "reserve judgement" [sic] until the investigation ends, she'll be "seeking new representation" if it turns out that the allegations are true. [[New York Magazine](http://nymag.com/intelligencer/2018/11/stormy-daniels-says-she-will-reserve-judgment-for-avenatti.html)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 16, 2018 at 8:28 AMNovember 15, 2018 at 11:37 PM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/morning-docket-11-16-18/&text=Morning%20Docket:%2011.16.18)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/morning-docket-11-16-18/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/morning-docket-11-16-18/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Calla Kessler/The Washington Post via Getty Images)

We’ll soon find out. [[USA Today](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2018/11/15/judge-rule-friday-cnn-white-house-credential/2014447002/)]

* “[W]e’re not going to leave any judges behind over these next two months.” According to Senator Tom Cotton, the Senate is apparently planning to work through Christmas and New Year’s Eve to confirm all of President Trump’s judicial nominees in an effort to head off any obstruction by the Democrats. # A 'Sort Of, Not Really' Cravath Match For The Holiday
## At least it is good news for first-year associates.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJuly 5, 2016 at 6:00 PMJuly 5, 2016 at 3:18 PM
20
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/a-sort-of-not-really-cravath-match-for-the-holiday/&text=A%20‘Sort%20Of,%20Not%20Really’%20Cravath%20Match%20For%20The%20Holiday)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/a-sort-of-not-really-cravath-match-for-the-holiday/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/a-sort-of-not-really-cravath-match-for-the-holiday/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
After close of business on July 1, when literally everyone had abandoned the firm to celebrate America’s long history of blowing things up, Jackson Walker announced its raises, which left a lot to be desired according to associates.

On the plus side, the Texas-based firm of over 350+ attorneys will adopt $180K salaries for first-year associates. This keeps the firm in the hunt for the top talent now that everyone and their mother in Texas raised salaries.

But the rest of the firm opened the email to find continued silence…

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The Compensation Committee continues to study how to update our compensation approach with respect to our other associates; again with focus on the need to attract and retain talent.

This isn’t necessarily bad news. The firm might announce more than generous raises throughout the firm in the coming weeks. But the only thing more frustrating than waiting until the holiday weekend to acknowledge associate compensation is teasing your associates with salary news and then saying, “um, we’ll get back to you.”

Until then, welcome to the 180K club, Jackson Walker first-years.

Remember, when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Cravath) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Cravath”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# All The Cool (And Smart) Kids Are Staying Away From Law School
## If you're smart, you probably want to steer clear of law school.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 5, 2018 at 12:36 PMApril 5, 2018 at 4:31 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/all-the-cool-and-smart-kids-are-staying-away-from-law-school/&text=All%20The%20Cool%20(And%20Smart)%20Kids%20Are%20Staying%20Away%20From%20Law%20School)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/all-the-cool-and-smart-kids-are-staying-away-from-law-school/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/all-the-cool-and-smart-kids-are-staying-away-from-law-school/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
So, the [“Trump Bump”](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/trump-bump/?rf=1) appears to be a real thing. That’s the notion that, in the wake of the surprise election of Donald Trump, more people are applying to go to law school. Indeed, [over 30 percent of recent applicants](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/02/over-30-percent-of-applicants-want-to-go-to-law-school-because-of-trump/) cite the 2016 election as a motivating factor in applying to law schools. While those numbers are encouraging for law school administrators that need to put butts in seats to keep the lights on, it doesn’t say anything about the quality of the applicants.

From both anecdotal and statistical metrics, we are in the midst of a law school [brain drain,](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/law-school-brain-drain/?rf=1) with the best and the brightest taking a hard pass at law school. Applicants [with terrible LSAT scores](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/law-school-applications-with-terrible-lsat-scores-are-soaring/) are applying to law schools in droves, causing a crisis in legal education. Remember, going to law school is only half of the “become a lawyer” equation. You still need to pass the bar exam when you graduate. And on that front, things don’t look so great — former head of the National Conference of Bar Examiners, Erica Moeser, called today’s law school graduates [“less able”](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/11/when-bar-scores-plummet-who-will-examine-the-examiners/) to pass the bar exam. Yikes.

Now comes another statistical measure from the most recent law school application cycle that indicates the overall quality of law students is on the decline. As [reported by](https://associatesmind.com/2018/03/30/top-university-students-avoiding-law-school-2018-edition/) Associate’s Mind, the number of law school applicants from top undergraduate institutions dropped 6.7 percent from 2016 to 2017. This is particularly bad since, after steady decline from 2008, last year’s applicant pool actually saw a small (1.2 percent) increase in people with undergrad degrees from elite institutions. With the most recent set of numbers, it’s clear last year was an aberration, and the overall downward trend is continuing.

# Fired Biglaw Partner Convicted Of Cyberstalking Former Colleagues
## Prosecutors say he was held "accountable for his yearslong harassment of his former law partners."
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 18, 2022 at 10:57 AM
16
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/fired-biglaw-partner-convicted-of-cyberstalking-former-colleagues/&text=Fired%20Biglaw%20Partner%20Convicted%20Of%20Cyberstalking%20Former%20Colleagues)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/fired-biglaw-partner-convicted-of-cyberstalking-former-colleagues/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/fired-biglaw-partner-convicted-of-cyberstalking-former-colleagues/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Yesterday, a federal jury in Manhattan convicted former K&L Gates partner Willie Dennis of three charges of cyberstalking.[ Dennis was accused ](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/ex-biglaw-partner-arrested-accused-of-cyberstalking-former-colleagues/)of sending thousands of threatening emails and text messages to partners at his former firm between the years of 2018 and 2020.

The campaign of problematic communications began after Dennis was fired from the firm. As [reported by](https://www.law360.com/articles/1540805/ex-k-l-gates-partner-convicted-of-cyberstalking-attys) Law360, that’s when the deluge of messages began:

During opening statements last week, prosecutors told the jury that after he was fired from K&L Gates, Dennis “flooded” three former colleagues with messages containing degrading names, violent imagery and threats against their families and careers.

Dennis’ messages included warnings like “I will find you” and “sleep with one eye open,” according to Assistant U.S. Attorney Stephanie Simon.

“They thought the defendant might come to their home or office and that he might even hurt them,” Simon told the jury.

Simon said Dennis’ harassment upended his former colleagues’ lives, causing one to move to a different state and another to sleep with a loaded gun under his pillow.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Dennis contended that the messages were “justified” because he was complaining about sexual harassment, racial discrimination, and management at the firm. Dennis has sued the firm over these allegations, and the case is stayed pending arbitration.

U.S. Attorney Damian Williams said of the conviction, “Dennis terrified his former colleagues to the point they had serious concerns for their own safety. Today, a unanimous jury has made sure that Dennis is accountable for his yearslong harassment of his former law partners.”

During the course of the case Dennis, who represented himself during the week long trial, also came under fire from presiding judge Jed Rakoff:

Dennis, a longtime member of K&L Gates’ corporate practice, gave an at-times erratic opening statement that prompted numerous objections from the government. Judge Rakoff rebuked the attorney for bringing up off-limits topics like his interactions with police officers and seemingly unrelated current events, such as the war in Ukraine.

“Please confine yourself to the issues in this case,” the judge told Dennis.

Judge Rakoff’s frustration appeared to mount before the trial began Tuesday when Dennis arrived a half-hour late for jury selection. The judge also chastised the defendant for continuing a long pattern of sending improper emails to the court.

“If I receive from any party in this case any email, I will consider holding that party in contempt of court,” said Judge Rakoff, to whom the case was transferred two months ago. “You are a serial violator of the one and only rule that I’ve stressed.”

# District Court Rules Proskauer Must Face Trial And Benchslaps The Firm In The Process
## The judge throws around some harsh words.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 25, 2018 at 4:01 PMApril 25, 2018 at 3:07 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/district-court-rules-proskauer-must-face-trial-and-benchslaps-the-firm-in-the-process/&text=District%20Court%20Rules%20Proskauer%20Must%20Face%20Trial%20And%20Benchslaps%20The%20Firm%20In%20The%20Process)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/district-court-rules-proskauer-must-face-trial-and-benchslaps-the-firm-in-the-process/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/district-court-rules-proskauer-must-face-trial-and-benchslaps-the-firm-in-the-process/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Northern District of Texas district judge David C. Godbey has found the Biglaw firm of Proskauer Rose has to stand trial in the case brought by the receiver in the Stanford Financial Ponzi scheme.

[Robert Allen Stanford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allen_Stanford) was convicted in 2012 of charges surrounding a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, and the appointed receiver is charged with protecting the interests of the legitimate creditors. As part of that effort, a lawsuit was brought against Proskauer and other Stanford attorneys alleging they were negligent and aided and abetted Stanford’s fraud in breach of their fiduciary duties.

Judge Godbey ruled Proskauer is not protected by the attorney immunity doctrine in a suit by the receiver and the trial should go forward. Proskauer appealed, but Judge Godbey [called that appeal](https://biglawbusiness.com/proskauer-rose-must-go-to-trial-on-stanford-receivers-claims/) “frivolous and dilatory.”

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Why don’t you tell us how you really feel.

As you might imagine, yesterday the firm[ filed](https://www.law360.com/texas/articles/1036958/proskauer-asks-5th-circ-to-stay-1-5b-stanford-trial) an emergency motion for stay:

“Proskauer requests an emergency stay from this court to prevent the district court from depriving Proskauer of its right to an orderly appeal to resolve serious issues of attorney immunity.”

The receiver has previously settled claims with Hunton & Williams — to the tune of $34 million — for their representation of Stanford.

# Kasowitz Facing Two Lawsuits Brought By Diverse Partners Who Say They Got Stiffed
## Both partners report a substantial cash shortfall.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJanuary 13, 2020 at 12:32 PMJanuary 13, 2020 at 4:59 PM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/kasowitz-facing-two-lawsuits-brought-by-diverse-partners-who-say-they-got-stiffed/&text=Kasowitz%20Facing%20Two%20Lawsuits%20Brought%20By%20Diverse%20Partners%20Who%20Say%20They%20Got%20Stiffed)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/kasowitz-facing-two-lawsuits-brought-by-diverse-partners-who-say-they-got-stiffed/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/kasowitz-facing-two-lawsuits-brought-by-diverse-partners-who-say-they-got-stiffed/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Marc Kasowitz (screenshot via YouTube)

Marc Kasowitz had an [altogether disastrous 2017](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/marc-kasowitz-is-waking-up-to-a-bad-morning/), but things have been fairly quiet ever since he [stepped back from Russiagate](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/kasowitz-checking-out-of-russiagate/) and handed the role of “ostensible lawyer spewing wild nonsense” job [over to Rudy Giuliani](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/esteemed-legal-scholars-giuliani-and-pirro-urge-scotus-to-decree-impeachment-illegal-under-marbury-v-madison/).

But last week, Kasowitz got sued by not one but TWICE. The two lawsuits, one in Texas and one in California, may be entirely independent but they have a lot in common. In both suits, a diverse former partner alleges that the firm stiffed him on pay before firing him. Both even allege that the firm was paying them on the same deficient scale.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[The first suit](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/kasowitz-facing-two-lawsuits-brought-by-diverse-partners-who-say-they-got-stiffed/2/) was brought by Kyung Lee, who joined the firm’s Houston restructuring practice in 2018. According to the complaint, the firm agreed to a $550K in annual comp for Lee’s first year on the job and then proceeded to pay him $20K/month — on target for $240K/year. When Lee asked for the remaining $310K, he claims that was told on October 15, 2019 that the firm would take a $51K offset and would pay him “$125,000 today” which doesn’t add up. He says that Kasowitz responded soon afterward by making “false allegations.” On October 16, he received the $125K and on October 17 he complained that he felt as though punitive actions were being taken against him. On October 18, he was fired. Lee noted that this was done without a proper vote of the firm’s Executive Committee.

[In the second suit](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/kasowitz-facing-two-lawsuits-brought-by-diverse-partners-who-say-they-got-stiffed/3/), San Francisco white collar partner David Fermino, a gay African-American attorney, alleges a number of discriminatory incidents from his time at the firm. Not to downplay the seriousness of those allegations — UPDATE: a Kasowitz spokesperson notes that the firm denies these allegations — let’s focus on the compensation issues because that’s where the two suits come together. Fermino, who joined Kasowitz in 2017, alleges that the firm promised him an annual salary of $400K. You’ll never believe what Fermino alleges happened next:

Between Plaintiff’s start date and December 2017, Kasowitz paid Plaintiff a salary of $20,000 per month, or $240,000 on an annualized basis, substantially less than his agreed upon compensation.

I guess $20K/month is a magic number! Fermino says the firm made a partial payment of the deficiency in January 2018 before reducing monthly compensation to $10K in April and later to $9K. Fermino then claims that Kasowitz made “false and defamatory statements” about him to others in the legal community before terminating him unilaterally… without the proper vote of the firm’s Executive Committee.

For its part, the firm informed Texas Lawyer that “[Kyung Lee’s allegations are false, and his claims are unfounded](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/01/08/houston-lawyer-alleges-kasowitz-fired-him-amid-compensation-dispute/).” The firm claims that Fermino misrepresented his book of business and only billed “about 10 hours per week,” which could certainly justify firing someone through a formal process as opposed to systematically dropping his pay.

Two partners, two different offices, two different specialties. And yet some disturbingly familiar allegations: diverse partners, paid an associate’s salary despite earlier agreements, subject to what they say are false claims when they raise complaints, and then unilateral termination without proper EC process.

These are two cases to keep an eye on.

(Check out the full complaints on the next two pages…)

# Biglaw Firm Feels The Weight Of The World On Its Shoulders After Merger Talks Fall Apart
## The firm needs try really hard to hold on tight to its top talent right now.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 6, 2023 at 5:17 PMMarch 6, 2023 at 4:45 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/biglaw-firm-feels-the-weight-of-the-world-on-its-shoulders-after-merger-talks-fall-apart/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Feels%20The%20Weight%20Of%20The%20World%20On%20Its%20Shoulders%20After%20Merger%20Talks%20Fall%20Apart)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/biglaw-firm-feels-the-weight-of-the-world-on-its-shoulders-after-merger-talks-fall-apart/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/biglaw-firm-feels-the-weight-of-the-world-on-its-shoulders-after-merger-talks-fall-apart/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Once you engage in merger talks to that degree, and then it breaks up, the perception can be that you are now really in play.

Because those firms that are at the top of the food chain know that there’s a lot of quality at Shearman & Sterling, and if they can make a run … they’re going to try to do so. So it’s imperative to try to keep those people.

— Brian Burlant, a managing director at legal recruiting firm E.P. Dine Inc., in [comments given to Law360](https://www.law360.com/articles/1582158) on the troubles Shearman & Sterling may be looking at in the wake of the firm’s [collapsed merger talks](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/rumored-merger-between-hogan-lovells-and-shearman-scrapped/) with Hogan Lovells. During the course of the merger talks, Shearman [conducted layoffs](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/shearman-sterling-associate-layoffs/) and lost a number of high-profile partners, as well as an [entire European team](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/03/03/shearman-dealt-another-major-blow-as-munich-team-quits-for-morgan-lewis-405-118476/). Burland emphasized the importance of the firm retaining top talent during this transitory period.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# The Pink Ghetto: When A Biglaw Partner Asks You About Prostitution During An Interview
## What was this partner thinking?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 12, 2016 at 4:45 PMSeptember 12, 2016 at 5:20 PM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/the-pink-ghetto-when-a-biglaw-partner-asks-you-about-prostitution-during-an-interview/&text=The%20Pink%20Ghetto:%20When%20A%20Biglaw%20Partner%20Asks%20You%20About%20Prostitution%20During%20An%20Interview)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/the-pink-ghetto-when-a-biglaw-partner-asks-you-about-prostitution-during-an-interview/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/the-pink-ghetto-when-a-biglaw-partner-asks-you-about-prostitution-during-an-interview/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

The new norm for Biglaw interviews?

Welcome back to [The Pink Ghetto](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/the-pink-ghetto/), a series where we take a look at some of the most appalling stories from one of the most sexist industries in the world: the legal profession. Today, we’ll be examining the way women in law school and law practice are treated based on their gender and perceived ties to feminism. These are real emails that we’ve received from real readers.

When you see things like this happening, say something. Together, we can inspire the change necessary to stop this disturbing behavior from being so prevalent in the law.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
I was over 40 when I started law school in 2009, and at the end of my first year we had to do a mock oral appellate argument. I thought I nailed mine but, afterwards, as the class was dismissed, the professor asked to speak with me. I was informed that while I obviously was both well-prepared and articulate, I came off as “hard” and “masculine” and that I should think about softening my tone and presentation.

The professor was a female, about 15 years older than I. I was so stunned (and hurt, honestly) that it wasn’t until later that I thought I should have asked her if she ever told any of the males in the class that they came off as hard and masculine and should think about softening their tone and presentation.

I was a law student who was hoping to land a Biglaw summer associate position for summer after my 2L year. I was top 15% at a regional law school, but one big firm that I interviewed with clearly did not think that I was in the running for a 2L summer position.

During one of the worst half hours of my career, the male partner zeroed in on the fact that I was a women’s studies major in college. He asked me if I was a “feminist” and “what was I thinking majoring in women’s studies.” Each time that I tried to bring one of his sexist interview questions back to my qualifications, he would say, “That’s not what I asked you.”

It finally culminated in him saying, “Let me ask you a question. Prostitutes. The ultimate feminists or the ultimate anti-feminists?” I was through at this point. So I told him, “Well, I guess it depends on the prostitute,” and then walked out.

# Baby Pls Don't Go: An Ode To Biglaw Special Bonuses
## Just when you thought you were out of Biglaw, they pull you back in.
By [BigLawBoiz](https://abovethelaw.com/author/biglawboiz/)  
onMarch 26, 2021 at 12:45 PMMarch 26, 2021 at 11:39 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/baby-pls-dont-go-an-ode-to-biglaw-special-bonuses/&text=Baby%20Pls%20Don’t%20Go:%20An%20Ode%20To%20Biglaw%20Special%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/baby-pls-dont-go-an-ode-to-biglaw-special-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/baby-pls-dont-go-an-ode-to-biglaw-special-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Please welcome [BigLawBoiz](https://www.instagram.com/biglawboiz/) (“BLB”) to the pages of Above the Law. BLB will be writing about what associate life is like in Biglaw.

You spent the last 12 months hunched over at your kitchen table redlining documents and fielding Zoom calls, pretending you’re wearing pants and have showered in the last three days.  You hardly saw the sunlight, and somehow in the midst of a global pandemic where the economy should be tanking you worked… more?  Well, your bonus check finally cleared.  You’re dipping your toe in the water to see what else is out there: greener pastures, work-life balance, more hands-on experience.  You never thought you’d be in Biglaw this long.  Most top out at the midlevel somewhere; it’s no secret that this is how the business model works.  Lawyers and law firms bank on it.

Well, it looks like a lot of people got wise to that business model, all while the SPAC craze kept M&A and Capital Markets activities at all-time highs.  Biglaw firms need their people, more than ever it may seem.  Goldman Sachs caught the business end of the chainsaw when a few of their analysts very publicly complained they “work too hard for this shit.”  Some Biglaw firms wised up and did what they know best: throw money at an issue and pretend it’s the same thing as respect.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
These bonuses are significant.  It is certainly a lot of money to give out to your team, and it makes sense — costs were certainly down.  Firms don’t have an entire office, or multiple offices, to keep lit up 24/7 (you paid your increased utilities bill), the extravagant summer programs did not happen (instead of firm-sponsored lunch at Michelin-starred restaurants, you ate a string cheese and Gatorade), and revenues were flat, if not up across many firms.  It’s good to see some of the wealthiest lawyers in the country spreading the love with their people who make the firms so successful.

However, let’s not mistake these as purely altruistic.  The way these bonuses are structured scream “Please don’t leave us!”  You get some now-ish, and some later.  How much later?  Well, wait until fall when we bring in a new class of associates.  These bonuses will not be “free,” and I don’t think are meant to reward associates for the past work they have done, but rather to entice them to stay through what could, and likely will, be a grueling few months.

With vaccine rollouts and cases decreasing, the COVID catastrophe will at some point end.  I’ve heard the rumors of back to office by July, or September.  The far-off dreams of 2022 return seem to have been crushed underneath Joe Biden’s feet as he tripped up the stairs.  If you thought you were busy last year, you better gear up for this year.  It will continue to be SPAC-tacular!  A true SPAC-tacle.  When the money is free, can you really blame banks and law firms for getting in on the SPAC-tion?

Firms really can’t afford to lose you.  They want to hire short-term staff and move associates from different groups into the hot spaces.  They just need the manpower.  You can stay.  You will get worked like a dog. (Side bar, dogs work the least out of any animal.  All dogs I’ve known spend their entire day sleeping.  Bad idiom.)  But you’ll get a nice little piece of change to make you feel special.  You can buy things that fill the void in your life, I know those red bottoms and rollies are looking real right now.

So, you have to ask yourself:  is it worth it?  You may have been ready to leave, maybe take a modest pay cut, but regain some control over your life.  Or do you double down on the golden handcuffs, spend the summer and leave when you get the “surprise” bonus?  But wait, then the winter bonus is only a few months away… might as well stay for that too… Maybe the model has changed.

[BigLawBoiz](https://www.instagram.com/biglawboiz/) (“BLB”) is a Biglaw associate in New York. BLB anonymously runs a popular [Instagram-based meme page](https://www.instagram.com/biglawboiz/) which chronicles and mocks the most absurd facets of life in Biglaw, corporate America, and being a lawyer in general. Who is BLB? BLB be could be the associate who’s two doors down, could be you — there’s a BLB inside of all of us.

## Credit Finance associates can find more information on this exciting opportunity in H-Town here.
By [KINNEY RECRUITING](https://bit.ly/3zzGAdh)  
onJuly 27, 2022 at 4:06 PMJuly 27, 2022 at 1:06 PM
1

[](https://abovethelaw.com/uploads/2022/07/AdobeStock_190442185-scaled.jpeg)One of our top 20 Am Law clients is looking for two Credit Finance associates with 2-4 years of experience for their highly regarded practice in their Houston office.

# The First International Law Firm In The World
## This firm has been in the game since the 18th century.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 11, 2018 at 6:18 PMDecember 11, 2018 at 2:41 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/the-first-international-law-firm-in-the-world/&text=The%20First%20International%20Law%20Firm%20In%20The%20World)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/the-first-international-law-firm-in-the-world/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/the-first-international-law-firm-in-the-world/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
What Biglaw firm lays claim to being the oldest international law firm?

Hint: The firm is considered to have been founded in 1743. The firm’s first client was the Bank of England, which it still advises today.

# Biden's Granddaughter, A D.C. Biglaw Associate, To Marry T14 Law School Grad At White House
## These Biglaw lovebirds will have a wonderful wedding at the White House.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 5, 2022 at 4:16 PMApril 6, 2022 at 9:46 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/bidens-granddaughter-a-d-c-biglaw-associate-to-marry-t14-law-school-grad-at-white-house/&text=Biden’s%20Granddaughter,%20A%20D.C.%20Biglaw%20Associate,%20To%20Marry%20T14%20Law%20School%20Grad%20At%20White%20House)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/bidens-granddaughter-a-d-c-biglaw-associate-to-marry-t14-law-school-grad-at-white-house/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/bidens-granddaughter-a-d-c-biglaw-associate-to-marry-t14-law-school-grad-at-white-house/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Naomi Biden and her Pop. (Photo by Ng Han Guan-Pool/Getty Images)

Love will be in the air in the nation’s capital this coming fall, when [Naomi Biden](https://www.linkedin.com/in/naomi-biden-95939874/), an associate at Arnold & Porter Kaye Scholer, marries her longtime boyfriend. Biden, of course, is granddaughter to President Joe Biden, and earlier this week, she announced on Twitter that the affair would be taking place at the White House.

Peter and I are endlessly grateful to my Nana and Pop for the opportunity to celebrate our wedding at the White House. We can’t wait to make our commitment to one another official and for what lies ahead.

— Naomi Biden (@NaomiBiden) [April 4, 2022](https://twitter.com/NaomiBiden/status/1511081396151984140?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
But who is this Peter character that the president’s granddaughter is planning to marry? Let’s dig in.

According to the New York Times, Naomi’s future husband is [Peter Neal](https://www.linkedin.com/in/nealpeter/) of Jackson Hole, Wyoming. Neal is a third-year student in his final semester at Penn Law. You may recognize his name as one of the creators of [My CARES Act Benefits](https://www.mycaresactbenefits.com/), an online quiz that calculates eligibility for federal relief. (Neal’s co-creator in this public-interest endeavor? His future wife, Naomi. Aww!) Per his LinkedIn profile, he spent the past summer working as an associate at Cooley. Assuming he received an offer, that would be awfully convenient because the firm just so happens to have an office in D.C.

While the location for their ceremony has not yet been announced, the couple’s reception will be held at the White House on November 19. The last wedding reception for a presidential family member to have been held there was in June 2008, in celebration of Jenna Bush’s marriage to Henry Hager.

Congratulations to the happy young couple, and may they survive and thrive together through wedded billable hours bliss!

# 'Don't Take Yourself Too Seriously': Advice On Side Hustles From A Lawyer Turned TV Star
## Make your side hustle work for you. Anything is possible!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 29, 2023 at 3:47 PMSeptember 29, 2023 at 1:48 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/dont-take-yourself-too-seriously-advice-on-side-hustles-from-a-lawyer-turned-tv-star/&text=‘Don’t%20Take%20Yourself%20Too%20Seriously’:%20Advice%20On%20Side%20Hustles%20From%20A%20Lawyer%20Turned%20TV%20Star)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/dont-take-yourself-too-seriously-advice-on-side-hustles-from-a-lawyer-turned-tv-star/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/dont-take-yourself-too-seriously-advice-on-side-hustles-from-a-lawyer-turned-tv-star/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Alan Barinholtz (Photo by JC Olivera/Getty Images)

Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

Don’t take yourself too seriously, and if there is something you love, do it. [It’s important to make a living, but] there are other things beyond the law. Find that thing that makes you feel good and stay relevant.

— [Alan Barinholtz](https://www.leplaw.com/attorney-profiles/alan-barinholtz), a personal injury lawyer who starred as Judge Alan Rosen in the Amazon Prime TV series [“Jury Duty,”](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jury_Duty_(2023_TV_series)) in comments given to the American Lawyer on how skills from side hustles can help in a career as an attorney. “Improv was a huge asset. What I learned more than anything: be prepared. Know your [stuff]. Know the facts. Know the law,” he told Am Law. “And then if you have the ability, improvise.”

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Career Alternatives](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/career-alternatives/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/in-house-counsel/), [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/), [Side Hustles](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/side-hustles/), [Small Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/small-law-firms-topic/)

# Above The Law’s 9th Annual Holiday Card Contest
## We look forward to your submissions. Thank you, and happy holidays!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 1, 2017 at 11:05 AMNovember 29, 2018 at 9:28 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/above-the-laws-9th-annual-holiday-card-contest/&text=Above%20The%20Law’s%209th%20Annual%20Holiday%20Card%20Contest)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/above-the-laws-9th-annual-holiday-card-contest/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/above-the-laws-9th-annual-holiday-card-contest/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s the most wonderful time of the year. Amid balmy “winter” weather mixed with a bonanza of [bonus news](https://abovethelaw.com/bonuses/), the holiday season is off to a great start. Jolly Old Saint Cravath was very kind this year, stuffing associates’ stockings with good cheer and [wads of cash](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/associate-bonus-watch-cravath-announces-its-2017-associate-bonuses/). The law firm holiday parties are starting to kick into gear, but the parties and paychecks pale in comparison to what’s about to get underway: Above the Law’s ninth annual holiday card contest. We’ve already received several emails asking about when this year’s contest would start. The answer: It starts today.

We are a legal website, so of course there are some rules to follow:

1. Because we are committed to the environment here at [Breaking Media](http://breakingmedia.com/), we will consider ONLY E-CARDS. You can certainly send us paper holiday cards via snail mail — our address is Above the Law / Breaking Media, 611 Broadway, Suite 907D, New York, NY 10012 — but they won’t be considered for this contest.

2. To submit an e-card, please email either a link to the card or the card itself (as an attachment) — but note that WE PREFER LINKS, if available — to [tips@abovethelaw.com](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Holiday%20Card%20Contest), subject line: “Holiday Card Contest.” The subject line is very important because it’s how we will comb through our inbox to collect the entries when picking finalists. If you don’t use the correct subject line, expect a lump of coal in your stocking.

3. Please limit submissions to holiday / Christmas cards that you view as WORTHY CONTENDERS. We’re looking for cards that are unusually clever, funny, or cool; we’re not interested in cards that are safe or boring (e.g., a beautiful winter landscape, a “Happy Holidays 2017,” and the law firm name). We’re seeking cards with some attitude, with that extra je ne sais quoi. If you send us a banal card, don’t be surprised if we [make fun of it](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/01/atl-holiday-card-contest-honorable-and-dishonorable-mentions/).

4. In your email, please include a BRIEF EXPLANATION of why this card is compelling — an explanation that we MIGHT QUOTE FROM if your nominee makes the finals (if you want to be anonymous, let us know). If you can’t offer an explanation, please rethink whether the card is a worthy contender (see rule #3, supra).

5. The deadline for submissions is two weeks from today: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 15, at 11:59 p.m. (New York time). No exceptions. If you’re reading this post after the deadline, then you don’t read Above the Law frequently enough.

text:
[  ](/)	[Home](/) | [Archive](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/archive/) | [RSS](/feed/) | [Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/howappealing) | [Contact](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

	

Thursday, July 20, 2017
“Brenda Hale to become supreme court’s first female president — reports; Lady Hale, who has long campaigned for greater diversity in the judiciary, is said to be taking up the role as three other supreme court posts are filled”: Nicola Slawson of The Guardian (UK) has [this report](https://www.theguardian.com/law/2017/jul/21/brenda-hale-to-become-supreme-courts-first-female-president-reports).

Posted at [10:18 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72263) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Louisville attorney John Bush confirmed 51-47 for seat on federal court of appeals”: Andrew Wolfson of The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Kentucky has [this report](http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/2017/07/20/louisville-attorney-john-bush-confirmed-51-47-seat-federal-court-appeals/494904001/).

Posted at [3:21 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72262) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“A Prisoner’s Only Writing Machine”: Daniel A. Gross has [this post](http://www.newyorker.com/books/page-turner/how-one-of-the-last-american-typewriter-companies-survives) online at The New Yorker.

Posted at [3:18 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72261) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“The Dark History of Defining ‘Family'”: [Mae Ngai](http://history.columbia.edu/faculty/Ngai.html) has [this essay](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/19/opinion/travel-ban-upheld-supreme-court.html) online at The New York Times.

Posted at [3:02 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72260) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“A judiciary transformed at blazing speed”: In today’s edition of The Washington Post, columnist Ronald A. Klain has [an op-ed](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/the-one-area-where-trump-has-been-wildly-successful/2017/07/19/56c5c7ee-6be7-11e7-b9e2-2056e768a7e5_story.html) that begins, “Progressives breathed a sigh of relief recently when Justice Anthony M. Kennedy decided to remain on the Supreme Court for presumably at least one more year. But no matter how long Kennedy stays, a massive transformation is underway in how our fundamental rights are defined by the federal judiciary.”

Posted at [2:58 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72259) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Protesters plan to show abortion on Jumbotron in downtown Louisville”: Deborah Yetter and Tessa Weinberg of The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Kentucky have [this report](http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/2017/07/20/abortion-protestors-depict-images-abortion-giant-tv-screen/495190001/), along with a related article headlined “[Buffer zone sought at Louisville abortion clinic ahead of Operation Save America protests](http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/2017/07/19/fed-seek-enforce-buffer-zone-around-louisville-abortion-clinic/492912001/).”

Posted at [1:44 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72258) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Senate confirms judge who equated abortion with slavery”: The Associated Press has [this report](http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_SENATE_JUDGE?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT).

And Alex Swoyer of The Washington Times reports that “[Senate confirms John Bush, Trump’s 6th Circuit Court pick](http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/jul/20/john-bush-trumps-6th-circuit-court-pick-confirmed-/).”

You can view the official roll call vote tally approving the nominee by a vote of 51-to-47 [at this link](https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=115&session=1&vote=00164).

Posted at [1:35 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72257) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Supreme Court’s Junior Justice Has to Run the Cafeteria; Don’t Eat There; Court tradition requires newcomers to serve on the cantina committee, field complaints about liberally salted oatmeal, conservative mayonnaise levels; Alito’s pudding parfait predicament”: Jess Bravin will have [this front page article](https://t.co/WXR3sII7w2) in Friday’s edition of The Wall Street Journal.

Posted at [1:28 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72256) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Sessions Vows to Stay on as Attorney General ‘as Long as That Is Appropriate'”: Eileen Sullivan and Rebecca R. Ruiz of The New York Times have [this report](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/20/us/politics/trump-jeff-sessions-attorney-general.html).

Posted at [12:57 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72255) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Chief Justice Roberts says criticism won’t stop judges”: The Associated Press has [this report](http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/A/AS_AUSTRALIA_JUSTICE_ROBERTS?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT).

Posted at [11:48 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72254) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Jones Day’s Review of Business-Related Cases in the Supreme Court’s October Term 2016”: As noted in [this news release](http://www.jonesday.com/jones-days-review-of-business-related-cases-in-the-supreme-courts-october-term-2016-07-19-2017/), the Jones Day law firm has issued [this white paper](http://www.jonesday.com/files/Publication/8db12238-56d1-4a46-b1d4-7f67d81c8cac/Presentation/PublicationAttachment/3403eb75-2675-4ba4-af89-823a372ac4da/Jones%20Day%20Review%20SCOTUS%202016.pdf).

Posted at [10:58 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72253) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“The Senate Is About To Confirm A Federal Judge Who Compared Abortion To Slavery; NARAL is pressuring five GOP senators to help sink John Bush’s nomination”: Jennifer Bendery of The Huffington Post has [this report](http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/john-bush-judge-trump-abortion_us_596f960be4b01696c6a239f6).

Todd Ruger of Roll Call reports that “[John Bush Nomination Exposes Partisan Divide; Kentucky jurist’s anonymous blog posts brings up questions of temperament](http://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/john-bush-nomination-exposes-partisan-divide).”

John Riley of Washington, DC’s Metro Weekly reports that “[Senate paves way for confirmation of anti-LGBTQ judge to 6th Circuit; LGBTQ groups alarmed at John K. Bush’s stances on marriage equality and privacy, and his use of anti-gay slurs](http://www.metroweekly.com/2017/07/senate-paves-way-confirmation-anti-lgbtq-judge-6th-circuit/).”

And Ian Millhiser of ThinkProgress has an essay titled “[Senate set to confirm unhinged right-wing blogger to powerful court: The Donald Trump of judges](https://thinkprogress.org/senate-set-to-confirm-unhinged-right-wing-blogger-to-powerful-court-fbcf89511efd).”

Posted at [10:54 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/20/#72252) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Will East Texas be able to keep patent cases, despite the Supreme Court? # Elite Firm Names New Partners While Biglaw Is In Meltdown Mode
## We're living in strange times. Congratulations!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 7, 2020 at 4:48 PMApril 8, 2020 at 10:37 AM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/elite-firm-names-new-partners-while-biglaw-is-in-meltdown-mode/&text=Elite%20Firm%20Names%20New%20Partners%20While%20Biglaw%20Is%20In%20Meltdown%20Mode)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/elite-firm-names-new-partners-while-biglaw-is-in-meltdown-mode/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/elite-firm-names-new-partners-while-biglaw-is-in-meltdown-mode/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

This is certainly not how I expected to be celebrating becoming a Skadden partner. That being said, we are adapting to the new normal. The traditional toasts have been replaced by online video chats and virtual congratulations, but it has certainly been a memorable experience.

— [Tracey Chenoweth](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/c/chenoweth-tracey-l), a member of the banking practice group at Skadden, commenting on her [ascension to the firm’s partnership](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/04/06/amid-industrywide-uncertainty-skadden-moves-forward-with-new-partner-promotions-405-57591/) during the COVID-19 pandemic. Earlier this month, the firm announced its [new partnership class](https://www.skadden.com/about/news-and-rankings/news/2020/04/skadden-names-new-partners): Chenoweth, [Dohyun Kim](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/k/kim-dohyun) (M&A), and [Jennifer Permesly](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/p/permesly-jennifer) (international arbitration) in New York; [David Clark](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/c/clark-david-r) (M&A) and [Marcie Lape](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/l/lape-marcie) (litigation) in Chicago; [Paul Schockett](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/s/schockett-paul) (tax) and [Julia York](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/y/york-julia-k) (antitrust/competition) in Washington, D.C.; [Peter Mair](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/m/mair-peter) (real estate) and [Virginia Milstead](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/m/milstead-virginia) (litigation) in Los Angeles; [Shu Du](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/d/du-shu) (China corporate) in Hong Kong; [Andrew Good](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/g/good-andrew-m) (white collar crime/government enforcement) in London; [Ken Kumayama](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/k/kumayama-ken-d) (IP) in Palo Alto; and [Jenness Parker](https://www.skadden.com/professionals/p/parker-jenness-e) (litigation) in Wilmington, Delaware. Nearly 70 percent of this class is made up of women or people of color. Congratulations!

# Top 5 Biglaw Firm Raises The Bar On Billable Diversity & Inclusion Hours
## Whoa! This is the highest number of hours that any firm has offered yet.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 11, 2021 at 11:19 AMFebruary 12, 2021 at 3:41 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/top-5-biglaw-firm-raises-the-bar-on-billable-diversity-inclusion-hours/&text=Top%205%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Raises%20The%20Bar%20On%20Billable%20Diversity%20&%20Inclusion%20Hours)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/top-5-biglaw-firm-raises-the-bar-on-billable-diversity-inclusion-hours/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/top-5-biglaw-firm-raises-the-bar-on-billable-diversity-inclusion-hours/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Recognizing the importance of diversity and inclusion in the legal profession, Biglaw firms have started to implement strategies to improve how their workforces operate when it comes to moving toward achieving equity. We’ve previously acknowledged [Dorsey & Whitney](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/biglaw-firm-introduces-diversity-hours-that-count-toward-associate-billable-requirements/), [Hogan Lovells](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/care-about-biglaw-diversity-well-now-you-can-bill-for-it/), [Reed Smith](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/the-first-biglaw-firm-to-offer-billable-diversity-hours-for-all-timekeepers/), and [Cooley](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/top-25-biglaw-firm-offers-bonus-eligible-diversity-inclusion-billable-hours/) as firms where approved diversity and inclusion-related work will be billable for attorneys and will count toward bonus thresholds. We’ve just received word that yet another leading law firm has had a successful program like this that’s been quietly running since summer 2020 — and this firm is offering the highest number of billable diversity and inclusion hours we’ve heard of yet.

Baker McKenzie — the firm that was [the first to announce 2020 bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/breaking-biglaw-bonus-season-comes-early-and-no-its-not-cravath/) and sits at #4 in the latest Am Law 100 rankings — rolled out its diversity and inclusion billable hours credit program in July 2020 when it announced the formation of an Anti-Racism Taskforce. Here’s an excerpt from the firm’s announcement:

The Firm’s Anti-Racism Taskforce will examine the Firm’s hiring processes, work allocation systems, partner promotions and other long-standing practices with a critical eye toward rooting out bias and increasing equity and inclusion. The Taskforce will work closely with the Firm’s leadership to bring about concrete change. The Firm’s recognizing and providing credit for attorney time spent on diversity and inclusion activities includes up to 125 hours annually in the US and Canada and 50 hours annually in Mexico.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Baker McKenzie’s 125 billable D&I hours dwarfs the offerings of all other firms we’ve covered by 75 hours. This is a major move in the right direction. Firm leadership shared their thoughts on why this was such an important step to take:

North America Chief Executive Officer, Colin Murray, said, “At Baker McKenzie, we stand united as a Firm in saying that Black lives matter. We are adopting meaningful, concrete changes within the Firm to dismantle institutional bias and to walk down the path to full inclusion and equity.”

Anna Brown, the Firm’s first Chief Inclusion and Diversity Officer, said, “Baker McKenzie is not neutral. We are committed to taking an affirmative stand and putting action behind our words. These actions are steps forward in those efforts, and we look forward to making meaningful, long overdue change.”

Congratulations to Baker McKenzie on its commitment to diversity, and for offering its attorneys a way to create a more inclusive workplace. If diversity billables are anything like bonuses, perhaps we’ll see more firms rushing to meet (or perhaps even beat) the firm’s 125-hour rule. Which firm will take the challenge?

[Baker McKenzie Forms Anti-Racism Taskforce to Build Inclusion and Equity Inside and Outside the Firm](https://www.bakermckenzie.com/en/newsroom/2020/07/antiracism-task-force) [Baker McKenzie]

# Morning Docket: 06.02.17
## * Let's get ready to rumble: the Trump administration seeks Supreme Court review -- and rescue -- of its travel ban. [[New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/02/us/politics/trump-travel-ban-supreme-court.html?&hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=first-column-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news&_r=0)] * In other federal judicial news, the Ninth Circuit, sitting en banc, held that courts cannot routinely shackle defendants during proceedings; Judge Alex Kozinski wrote the majority opinion, and former Kozinski clerk Judge Sandra Ikuta wrote the dissent. [[How Appealing](http://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/060117.html#071777)] * Judge Nicholas Garaufis (E.D.N.Y.) -- who isn't shy about [telling lawyers how he really feels](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/was-this-judges-reprimand-of-kirkland-ellis-justified/) -- has a new bee in his Article III bonnet: "I’m sick and tired of lawyers from white-shoe law firms marching into my courtroom and getting a deferred-prosecution agreement for their clients." [[ABA Journal](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/federal_judge_is_sick_and_tired_of_white_shoe_law_firms_getting_deferred_pr)] * Why did President Donald Trump hire Marc Kasowitz to represent him in the Russia inquiry -- and could DJT already be second-guessing that decision? [[Weekly Standard](http://www.weeklystandard.com/trump-considering-a-d.c.-insider-as-counsel-to-handle-russia-investigation/article/2008301)] * Speaking of the Russia probe, Robert Mueller is getting some high-powered help: outgoing Justice Department official Andrew Weissmann joins his former boss's team. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/articles/930213)] * Interesting new data from our friends at NALP: the $180K starting salary might not be as widespread as you think. [[Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/06/01/despite-jump-to-180k-for-big-law-associates-median-salary-stalls/)] * President Trump plans to withdraw the U.S. from the Paris climate deal -- but withdrawal can't be finalized until near the end of his term because of the accord’s legal structure and language. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-to-announce-us-will-exit-paris-climate-deal/2017/06/01/fbcb0196-46da-11e7-bcde-624ad94170ab_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-banner-main_parisexit-3pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&utm_term=.0cc1b3102046)]
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onJune 2, 2017 at 9:00 AMJune 2, 2017 at 9:03 AM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/morning-docket-06-02-17/&text=Morning%20Docket:%2006.02.17)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/morning-docket-06-02-17/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/morning-docket-06-02-17/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

* In other federal judicial news, the Ninth Circuit, sitting en banc, held that courts cannot routinely shackle defendants during proceedings; Judge Alex Kozinski wrote the majority opinion, and former Kozinski clerk Judge Sandra Ikuta wrote the dissent.
